[Scarpelli]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Scarpelli]: of eight ward representations and then three at large candidates.

[Scarpelli]: It's bothersome that the question of equity comes around and gets thrown around easily.

[Scarpelli]: And being uniformed and giving people the opportunity to run for office.

[Scarpelli]: And we talked about all the pluses.

[Scarpelli]: I remember because I fought against those pluses, remember?

[Scarpelli]: I was against charter review for a long, long time.

[Scarpelli]: And it took a lot of talking to different communities, talking to colleagues in different communities and understanding from members of the charter review team and surveys and really understanding the importance of equity and what that meant.

[Scarpelli]: And this format that you're proposing and you're changing is an absolute shame to the community

[Scarpelli]: that has worked for two years, over 200 meetings, and all identified an eight and three format.

[Scarpelli]: We talk about why are people coming out?

[Scarpelli]: Why are people not connected to this process?

[Scarpelli]: And we identified the fact that we don't have board representation, and the fact that maybe there might be someone in that community that hasn't come out to vote,

[Scarpelli]: that re-energizes that community to be part of this process.

[Scarpelli]: What an opportunity.

[Scarpelli]: Then we talk about running in as an at-large member and how expensive that would be.

[Scarpelli]: And how many people, if you look around this reel, we all look the same, most of us.

[Scarpelli]: And most of us work together to get funding one way or the other.

[Scarpelli]: But to run for an office, you know what it takes?

[Scarpelli]: 20, 25,000 possibly.

[Scarpelli]: And looking at ward representation opens up the avenues for so many of the underprivileged that would never, ever, ever have the opportunity.

[Scarpelli]: Now, I know we could say that no district representation is ward representation.

[Scarpelli]: Misleading and not true.

[Scarpelli]: It's good for their future in the business of politics.

[Scarpelli]: So, and then coming out that evening to bring this forward.

[Scarpelli]: Now, as I will speak as a City Councilor for the City of Medford, who is the chairperson that brought a full-time recreation department to the City of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: When we started that program under Mayor Burke at the time, we really wanted to focus that when we started, it was really a very thin program when it talked about staffing, funding.

[Scarpelli]: It was really supposed to be a self-sustaining program.

[Scarpelli]: And as we move forward, we were supposed to have been growing with our community and enhancing programs like we're talking about tonight.

[Scarpelli]: But the, the recreation department is that department.

[Scarpelli]: So listen, there's one Councilor that Ms.

[Scarpelli]: McDonald, I've spoken to you directly and I can honestly look you in the eye and apologize because I let my ego get in the way when I was against charter review for the fact of the ward representation.

[Scarpelli]: But for one Councilor, I sat back and you realize when you talk to different groups and different people and

[Scarpelli]: you know, notwithstanding the respect the council that's of color on this council, but I've spoken to many people of color in our community that feel that they don't have a platform to run.

[Scarpelli]: and put everything on the table and understand as we move forward, there was nothing that we pushed through or you leave all the negativity behind and say, we did this the way we should have done it.

[Scarpelli]: And I think it's important because I, again, I've done that and I've talked to a lot of professionals that have talked about this process and other communities as professionals, whether they're zoning consultants, attorneys, or worked for different municipalities.

[Scarpelli]: this is the difference with what we've done so far and where the gaps are and where the cries are from the community.

[Scarpelli]: So again, I appreciate the time to listen.

[Scarpelli]: I know that in totality, I think that's probably the biggest thing that I've heard.

[Scarpelli]: I know that last night's meeting kind of answered some things, but I think the two biggest things that if we can come out of it is if there's a way that we could possibly work with our consultants to try to find

[Scarpelli]: a way to simplify.

[Scarpelli]: what those changes are and what we're really doing in those corridors.

[Scarpelli]: So it's not these maps that are real tiny so people can understand them a little bit better and just bullets where I hate to say it.

[Scarpelli]: Someone said to me, yes, this is Georgia.

[Scarpelli]: I'm 78 years old, and I just don't understand all this.

[Scarpelli]: This is so confusing to me.

[Scarpelli]: What does this mean for my house and my future here in Metroton?

[Scarpelli]: I couldn't answer them because it's specific to the area.

[Scarpelli]: You're seeing time and time again, Mr. President, that

[Scarpelli]: with increased fees, increased fines, no appeals process.

[Scarpelli]: I've talked to a few neighboring communities, talked to their commissioners, their traffic and parking directors, and I gave them scenarios.

[Scarpelli]: One scenario was a senior citizen who parked behind

[Scarpelli]: Colleen's and unfortunately, she left her handicapped placard on her dashboard.

[Scarpelli]: She didn't hang it on the rear view mirror.

[Scarpelli]: When she came out, she received a ticket, I believe it was 1201.

[Scarpelli]: She got in her car, she drove to the parking department at 1210 and said, this is the situation.

[Scarpelli]: I'm handicapped, this is my placard.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, I didn't hang it.

[Scarpelli]: And they said, you can appeal it.

[Scarpelli]: So they were generous enough to help her appeal it out front, to walk through the appeal.

[Scarpelli]: By the time she got home, she was notified that the appeal didn't go through, and she'd have to pay the ticket.

[Scarpelli]: She called City Hall, and I believe at the time, the Chief of Staff was overseeing the process, and her words directly were, there's no gray area here.

[Scarpelli]: It's either yes or no, and that's it.

[Scarpelli]: neighboring communities, you've talked to their commissioners.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, there are gray areas and there are options.

[Scarpelli]: So the next option on the appeal would have to go to the courts and on $150 ticket, this resident would then have to pay $250 to then appeal this at the next level so someone can listen to her.

[Scarpelli]: And again, one of the most vulnerable members of our community not being heard.

[Scarpelli]: And, um,

[Scarpelli]: That followed up with many residents of South Medford calling me and saying, George, listen, I drive my car on the weekends.

[Scarpelli]: And sometimes I have to take it out if I need it for work.

[Scarpelli]: But then when I come home, I realize that the G-Zone is now permitted to people that aren't residents of Medford because they bought a pass.

[Scarpelli]: And they're seeing the anger and the frustration.

[Scarpelli]: We're talking about situations with the business community.

[Scarpelli]: residents we're talking about supporting our businesses right our local businesses well now let's say you own a real estate company you in medford square you now pay for that pass which is 150 or 125 you pay for that in the past that was good throughout the city now you have to now buy another pass fee to get permitted and then if you have to show a house let's say in west medford so there's so many inequities here and it seems like

[Scarpelli]: We want to save small businesses.

[Scarpelli]: We want to support our business community.

[Scarpelli]: But in the same breath, we're putting in these hurdles and roadblocks and hurting what we're looking for.

[Scarpelli]: We have to remember, when the Traffic and Parking Department was implemented, it was made to really support the business community and keeping

[Scarpelli]: non-residents from parking, especially on the one-on-one route or the bus route that goes to the express bus, and parking there all day in front of a business, and then these outsiders take a spot for the whole entire day.

[Scarpelli]: Now in South Metro, from what I'm being told from the neighbors, there are cars that people don't live in the city.

[Scarpelli]: They get parking, they walk to the green line, they're gone all day, their car's in front of their house, and then they come home, they don't have parking.

[Scarpelli]: because we've then, you know, we've sold their spot, we've rented their spot in front of their home.

[Scarpelli]: So there's a lot of concerns, you know, there are so many others that come to mind that I think that we really need to sit down with the traffic department and the new director and get some clarity so we can help these residents.

[Scarpelli]: I think that, like, again, I think the G zone, it has to be some clarity in where the pilot program's going from here.

[Scarpelli]: The appeals process that there has to be something in place that someone in-house walks through, at least looks at an appeal, that it's something that's blatant that could support our resident, especially most vulnerable, that we have that in place.

[Scarpelli]: We look at our business community and even invite Chamber of Commerce to that

[Scarpelli]: to the meeting if we can, Mr. President, to a subcommittee meeting and get their input to see where we're going.

[Scarpelli]: educate ourselves, help educate the community, and then at the same time add any input that we can that at least the homework that I've done from neighboring communities that were very, very simple, simple ads that really, really could change a lot and really support our community.

[Scarpelli]: Well, a fellow councilor said that there are some of the wards, we could play it back, but some of the wards are so small,

[Scarpelli]: that we maybe might not need ward representation in such small wards.

[Scarpelli]: I wrote it by word.

[Scarpelli]: Just to get better or fix what's been wrong here.

[Scarpelli]: And again, this is coming from a place where I was against it.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President for allowing me the opportunity to speak on

[Scarpelli]: uh, true legend here in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: Um, when we know that Mr. Granada has been fighting a good fight for some time now.

[Scarpelli]: Um, but when, uh, we sure when God came calling this past week, um, we knew he now has one of the best people Medford ever had to offer to sit by his side.

[Scarpelli]: Um, Mr. Granada was so entrenched in our community and had so much love and passion for the city that I remember the time when I first started

[Scarpelli]: the option of running for school committee, I had to go sit with Mr. Granara to get his blessing.

[Scarpelli]: Not for the fact that he was the God, but it was so important to get his blessing so he can talk to you and explain to you what it truly meant to be an elected official in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: He made me understand that the reason why we become elected officials

[Scarpelli]: is the work that you are doing for the community, for the residents of the city, not for yourself, not for yourself, anything to gain any self-worth or for you personally, but what's best for the community.

[Scarpelli]: I think that when you first hear some of the things, I know that people don't know this, but Mr. Granara was a major factor in the Middlesex Sheriff's Offices and Trevor Katushin

[Scarpelli]: wrote this past week.

[Scarpelli]: It is with a heavy heart that I must inform you all the former Special Sheriff John Granara Esquire has passed away.

[Scarpelli]: Our thoughts and prayers are with his entire Granara family during this difficult time.

[Scarpelli]: A graduate of Matanon High School, Boston College, Suffolk University Law School, John Granara served the MSO with distinction in the highest levels.

[Scarpelli]: He began as the MSO's Chief Legal Counsel in March 1997, serving until 2009 of August.

[Scarpelli]: when he was appointed as Special Sheriff.

[Scarpelli]: Following the passing of the Sheriff Jimmy DePaulo in November of 2010, Special Sheriff Granara ably ran this agency until the appointment of Sheriff Katushin.

[Scarpelli]: Providing leadership at the pivotal time for the Middlesex Sheriff's Office, he was an invaluable source of knowledge, leadership, and friendship to me and many others throughout his tenure.

[Scarpelli]: It was our great privilege to have him remain as a Special Sheriff until August of 2011.

[Scarpelli]: John's legacy is public service included his time in the method school committee from 74 to 77 and his election to the Massachusetts House of Representatives in 76 representing his beloved hometown of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: In his memory, the half the flags in Middlesex jails were all lowered to half staff.

[Scarpelli]: Um, I know I read council bears read a few things that Mr. Granada did, but he did every

[Scarpelli]: He did more than people even knew.

[Scarpelli]: There was a lot of things, whether it's a celebration parade in Medford, whether it's supporting different programs that no one knew about, it was Mr. Granauer that did the work behind the scenes.

[Scarpelli]: And he kept a tradition that I thought was so valuable and so needed for our veterans that I believe it was, I said Memorial Day, but I believe it's Memorial Day, not Veterans Day, I believe.

[Scarpelli]: that working together with the members of the American Legion and the Elks, they would have our presentation and he would set a day of remembrance that you had to be there, you couldn't miss.

[Scarpelli]: So he was a special individual and someone that this city will miss, but if you've known John Granara, please share a story.

[Scarpelli]: Don't let his,

[Scarpelli]: his work fade away.

[Scarpelli]: Let that name stick with you, because this is what the city is lacking today.

[Scarpelli]: The reason why you see such divide is because people like John Granara aren't here to bring these groups together.

[Scarpelli]: So to the Granara family, we send our deepest condolences, and I'd love to, if we can, leave this meeting in his honor, Mr. President, and thank you for the time.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Another long time battle.

[Scarpelli]: Mr. Evangelista fought hard to be there for his loving wife and his two daughters, like he's always been.

[Scarpelli]: And unfortunately,

[Scarpelli]: He was taken from us and hopefully is resting in peace now.

[Scarpelli]: I know that the Evangelista family worked so hard, especially Julianne and Lisa.

[Scarpelli]: We all know Lisa, who's worked for the city for many, many years.

[Scarpelli]: I'd like to say she ran the city while Mike McGlynn was the mayor for those many, many years, and then moved over to the school department for many years.

[Scarpelli]: responses over the last year as we continually struggle to effectively fund our priorities, especially our school priorities due to the cost of inflation.

[Scarpelli]: Our administration has continued the process of reviewing department overtime budgets and procedures.

[Scarpelli]: Since February 2024 especially, I've been focusing on OT even more and working with all department heads that have OT line items in their budget to make sure all public funds are being used the best way possible and to make sure there is not misuse or overuse of such funds.

[Scarpelli]: The city's obligation to fund overtime is necessary to ensure the general public's safety, fulfill contractual obligations, and for the efficient operations of our community.

[Scarpelli]: However, we must be strategic in how the staffing is deployed as the funding resources are extremely limited and there are critical needs throughout our school district and city.

[Scarpelli]: Overtime is a crucial component

[Scarpelli]: of every municipality's budget and operations.

[Scarpelli]: We need DPW crews out on the streets plowing snow, removing trees that block roadways, and other critical tasks to keep our roadways accessible and safe.

[Scarpelli]: Police and fire OT for several reasons.

[Scarpelli]: In some circumstances, we need building inspectors to be able to visit homes and make determinations on living conditions.

[Scarpelli]: But we need to manage how overtime is allocated so we don't create a situation

[Scarpelli]: where we're spending taxpayers' money unnecessarily.

[Scarpelli]: That's why we're working with the department heads to develop a policy that enables them to manage their time to their team effectively and implement the overtime procedures that meets the needs of our constituency.

[Scarpelli]: The police department has done a much better job curbing overtime and has lowered the police overtime budget from about $2 million in 2018

[Scarpelli]: to an average number of 1.2 million for the past four years, a reduction of over 35%.

[Scarpelli]: The fire chief and mayor's office, the human resources director, are working diligently on accountability as it relates to OT.

[Scarpelli]: As one example, 28 letters have been issued to staff putting them on notice that their sick time use, which causes the need for overtime, seems excessive.

[Scarpelli]: Within the DPW, we hired DPW commissioners to help manage the department, specifically the OT budget.

[Scarpelli]: The topic on the agenda is how overtime is managed in our building department.

[Scarpelli]: We cannot have a union member fielding calls and assigning overtime shifts to themselves and their fellow employees.

[Scarpelli]: That presents a conflict that we made this change over the years.

[Scarpelli]: This did find to be necessary change, especially when almost $50,000 was paid out to overtime during the period my chief of staff was out on maternity leave.

[Scarpelli]: Our current building commissioner fields the calls from dispatch as part of department responses hierarchy and works within the written protocol to determine the immediate life safety status situations in an effort to determine the need for an inspector on scene.

[Scarpelli]: If the situation does not present an urgent need to respond, the commissioner will decline to send an inspector.

[Scarpelli]: The address is tracked and scheduled for follow-up by an inspector the next day.

[Scarpelli]: In instances where our commissioner is unavailable, our former commissioner is contacted and makes a determination.

[Scarpelli]: The former commission has received less than a handful of calls over the last year and has paid $60 per call.

[Scarpelli]: The building department continues to develop protocol and the training to fine tune the best possible responses of the concerns and staff welcome construction feedback.

[Scarpelli]: Mayor Kern.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Now, what I've been hearing is nothing what was just read.

[Scarpelli]: It's called Crew.

[Scarpelli]: And we didn't have a slip.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't have any docks.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't have a boathouse.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't have anything.

[Scarpelli]: And we were borrowing skulls from different

[Scarpelli]: committed young people really drove this when we first started it to where we are today.

[Scarpelli]: And I think it's so amazing that we have state champions in front of us right now with committed coaches and kids looking to go to the next level, colleges, universities, and participate in crew at that level.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's just amazing feet and see where we've gone.

[Scarpelli]: And you know what, I'll say it here.

[Scarpelli]: I've talked to a bunch of parents that I work in recreation and one of the,

[Scarpelli]: the most attractive pieces of our puzzle in Somerville is our boathouse.

[Scarpelli]: And what we can do, we have summer programs using rowing crew and the different avenues of community that crew really brings to Medford.

[Scarpelli]: And I'll say it publicly, I would love to see the mayor

[Scarpelli]: use our CPA money to look down the line to building us a true boathouse over at home else stadium I think that, to me, would be full circle and look at something that you know we have an avenue, we have a funding mechanism in place.

[Scarpelli]: Now all we need is a reason for it.

[Scarpelli]: And you've given us this reason tenfold.

[Scarpelli]: So I want to congratulate all of you coaches.

[Scarpelli]: I know that Mr. Maloney was in the forefront years ago when people told him that this wasn't going to happen.

[Scarpelli]: And I believe if maybe some people remember, when we first started, they put a couple of rowing machines

[Scarpelli]: in what's now the boys locker basketball locker room in the gym.

[Scarpelli]: Is it still there do you guys still use that area.

[Scarpelli]: It was like that's all we had.

[Scarpelli]: We had four, and people were just taking turns, jumping in so we've gone a long way so I commend all of you for pushing this forward.

[Scarpelli]: And it's amazing when you listen to other people from different communities, when they talk about

[Scarpelli]: What Medford crew is doing at the regard is and what they're doing at different events, and how you're seeing sportsmanship and and pride in community and this is what it's all about, you know, in.

[Scarpelli]: Traditionally, it was what hockey, football, baseball, right?

[Scarpelli]: Now you're seeing lifetime sports where you're seeing people using crew to go to the next level in academia, and then taking that to the next level and really promoting something that's really healthy and positive in our community.

[Scarpelli]: So I know I'm winded, but I just wanted to

[Scarpelli]: I like so much pride with all the medals on our athletes and coaches standing there stoically and I appreciate all this hard work.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you and congratulations.

[Scarpelli]: So, typical fashion, Friday we get emails from the mayor's office with $7.5 million.

[Scarpelli]: Tuesday we come to a meeting, we're gonna vote on it.

[Scarpelli]: As a responsible city councilor, I will now invoke our Rule 21, close the meeting, and ask for an open meeting with everybody to talk about this in more depth.

[Scarpelli]: Something that's unheard of, has never been heard of, never been done before, but council leadership suspends the rules of the meeting and imposes a vote to not invoke Rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: Done, you can't talk about it.

[Scarpelli]: But I will tell you, the council had five subcommittee meetings to talk about a city council newsletter.

[Scarpelli]: Five.

[Scarpelli]: And guess what that, that's free, nothing.

[Scarpelli]: But, the paper's adding up to $7.5 million and possibly more.

[Scarpelli]: They don't wanna talk about it.

[Scarpelli]: So, what do we do?

[Scarpelli]: We move on to the next meeting, and they said okay.

[Scarpelli]: I reach out to my state representative and I asked him, what is the plan?

[Scarpelli]: What can I do?

[Scarpelli]: And they said, okay, legal from the state said you can now invoke Mass General Law 43, section 22.

[Scarpelli]: That supersedes any method rule, shuts the meeting down.

[Scarpelli]: Well, we get to the next meeting.

[Scarpelli]: Our leadership team does the same exact thing.

[Scarpelli]: Suspends the rules.

[Scarpelli]: Says they cannot impose rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: I then invoke.

[Scarpelli]: Section 22, council leadership says, no, you can't do that.

[Scarpelli]: Against the rule, against the law.

[Scarpelli]: Because what was going to be said is this.

[Scarpelli]: And listen closely, because this is how real communities do it.

[Scarpelli]: In 2009, working in the city of Somerville, Mayor Joe Hurtatone was at a crossroads with his community.

[Scarpelli]: Big cuts looming.

[Scarpelli]: He convenes a group, a working group, a financial working group that consisted of financial minds from Tufts, MIT, Harvard, banking leaders.

[Scarpelli]: You had the Sloans from Century Bank.

[Scarpelli]: You had his financial team present.

[Scarpelli]: You had community leaders and business leaders all in a row.

[Scarpelli]: And they worked on a plan because they said you needed to figure out three things before you wanted to go to Novartis.

[Scarpelli]: One, how do we get there?

[Scarpelli]: We still don't know how we got here, at least publicly, there's nothing been mentioned.

[Scarpelli]: Two, how do we fix it?

[Scarpelli]: Three, how does this never happen again?

[Scarpelli]: That's what we were taught.

[Scarpelli]: Well, they came out and they said, okay, this is what we're going to do.

[Scarpelli]: We're going to look at traffic and parking fees.

[Scarpelli]: Not going to make people happy, but they're going to take that money.

[Scarpelli]: They're going to increase those fees.

[Scarpelli]: They're going to take that money, and that's going to be dedicated solely to the school department.

[Scarpelli]: Boom.

[Scarpelli]: Need taken away.

[Scarpelli]: Next.

[Scarpelli]: We need streets and sidewalks.

[Scarpelli]: How do we figure that out?

[Scarpelli]: The focus is fees and fines for trash and building.

[Scarpelli]: And boom.

[Scarpelli]: Developers paid for that.

[Scarpelli]: And then the third piece, the most important piece, they sat together and they said, well, what can we do so this never happens again?

[Scarpelli]: How do we bring Somerville out of this?

[Scarpelli]: Well, they started this little project called Assembly Row.

[Scarpelli]: And now, whether you like it or not, there's a lot of money coming into the city.

[Scarpelli]: Now, maybe you might question the growth, maybe question how they got there.

[Scarpelli]: That's not what I'm saying.

[Scarpelli]: What I'm saying is, that was an open process

[Scarpelli]: with financial minds that sat together to find a solution.

[Scarpelli]: What has happened here, both in the fire department and the school department, it's been done in a vacuum.

[Scarpelli]: Nobody knows.

[Scarpelli]: I know that a member of the community did file a FOIA request asking information for, we're waiting on that, hopefully we get that soon, that we can share with the community of what

[Scarpelli]: was shared, minutes, any notes, anything taken with this financial group?

[Scarpelli]: Well, it's a pretty in-depth opinion, I think.

[Scarpelli]: You know, we, as a city councilor, it's my responsibility and our responsibility to make sure that we are the financial stewards of our residents' budgets and making sure that our tax money is being spent appropriately.

[Scarpelli]: One thing we realized in our communities without, like I said, without a newspaper, we found it very difficult to get information out, and this being a good example.

[Scarpelli]: So a few months back a group was organized called All Medford and the All Medford group started to really educate and communicate and really bring pride back to Medford and it's been super successful.

[Scarpelli]: We've had hundreds if not thousands of people

[Scarpelli]: join our group, and when I say our group, I as a member, as our group.

[Scarpelli]: And we're now jumping right into a very serious, you know, situation and big step here in Medford, which is an override, Proposition 2 and F overrides and a debt exclusion.

[Scarpelli]: So what I'd like to do, if you don't mind, John, I'd like to start with

[Scarpelli]: explaining to our constituents and our viewers that there are three votes that they'll be taking.

[Scarpelli]: They'll be question six, question seven, and question eight.

[Scarpelli]: Question six is a debt exclusion for a rebuild of a new fire station headquarters on Main Street.

[Scarpelli]: That's a 30 million dollar project

[Scarpelli]: that I will share with you.

[Scarpelli]: The firefighters have come out publicly and they are not supporting the override for the fact that, you'll see a trend as I go through my speech today, but you'll see that there weren't really, the firefighters weren't involved in the final decision making of that fire station.

[Scarpelli]: And they're,

[Scarpelli]: In the conversations with the union leaders, one of the major issues is that there was really no, there was no partnership involved.

[Scarpelli]: No one, no firefighters were really involved in the final decisions.

[Scarpelli]: And what we were heard from firefighter Marcelino, Danielle Marcelino, who's the secretary for the union, she explained that they would not support the debt exclusion for the fire station because

[Scarpelli]: It was an inferior product and it's not set up for success as they move forward in the lives of future Medford firefighters.

[Scarpelli]: So with that, they said, you know, let's be responsible enough to share with the community that they would rather not let the citizens of Medford suffer with the tax

[Scarpelli]: just to check a box.

[Scarpelli]: So they responded back and they're not going to support it.

[Scarpelli]: So question six is about a new fire headquarters on Main Street.

[Scarpelli]: And question seven was presented from the mayor.

[Scarpelli]: for an override in question seven is $3.5 million of our property, our real estate taxes for our community for 2025 and from the general operations of Medford public school, $3 million for the Medford public schools, which includes but not limited for teachers, literacy coaches, behavior specialists, and administrative assistants and so on.

[Scarpelli]: Question 8 was put forth asking for a $4 million override tax from our real estate and personal properties for 2025 as well.

[Scarpelli]: And they're looking for increasing access to the arts and vocational programs and expanding classroom instructional opportunities.

[Scarpelli]: These are simple taxes and they were put forth, and I'll publicly say, as scare tactics from the administration.

[Scarpelli]: We can see that the overrides, and let me just educate everybody a little bit because some people don't really understand what a debt exclusion is in comparison to a Proposition 2.5 override.

[Scarpelli]: A debt exclusion is a tax to the community, to the residents, that will be put on their taxes every year until the project that it's funding is complete.

[Scarpelli]: So if it's $30 million for a new fire station, you would then start the clock with paying off that bond of $30 million.

[Scarpelli]: When that $30 million is paid, that tax will come off the resident's tax roll.

[Scarpelli]: So they won't see that tax anymore once it's paid.

[Scarpelli]: The misconception is the Proposition 2.5 override

[Scarpelli]: is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: You will get taxed a certain percentage from your home's assessed value, your real estate tax.

[Scarpelli]: Which is going up, by the way, correct?

[Scarpelli]: And I'll explain more with that.

[Scarpelli]: And with that process, that's a tax that's being misled in the public by people that are saying that if it's just $400 for the year, it's not just $400 for a year.

[Scarpelli]: Okay, let's start off by saying that when that tax is starting is January of 2025.

[Scarpelli]: So it's voted in November Wow, it'll go into place starting in January of 2025 which our residents most of our residents Won't be prepared for that

[Scarpelli]: We'll now start that tax and at the end of every year There is some understanding that some taxpayers have reached out to me and said oh, yeah, then then it's done I said no It doesn't what ends up happening is that tax bump that you're going to see for this override will then compound every year Every year at least two and a half percent every year.

[Scarpelli]: It'll stay with you forever never goes away never goes away now in clear up a few other misconceptions

[Scarpelli]: The comment that we're hearing is, it's just this, it's just that, it's not true.

[Scarpelli]: We know that this council has put forth in the past rent control, transfer tax, a renter's and owner's registry fee, and what we're looking at down the line is a new high school.

[Scarpelli]: Something that has already been taken out of free cash to start that process.

[Scarpelli]: And we're looking at a close to a, if it's a refurbished, maybe $200 million.

[Scarpelli]: And if for a new high school, it's $400 million.

[Scarpelli]: Just for an example, neighboring community just did their high school.

[Scarpelli]: Debt exclusion was put in for over $240 million.

[Scarpelli]: It's $1,000 more a year in taxes for each household.

[Scarpelli]: $1,000 more for each household, okay.

[Scarpelli]: So it's not just what people are saying.

[Scarpelli]: Now, I know the other side, the Yes Group, has a calculator in place.

[Scarpelli]: They do.

[Scarpelli]: They do.

[Scarpelli]: And the calculator is misleading because we've had phone calls from different organizations, different people that have questioned that, saying that I put my address in and the number that's coming out is wrong because my assessed value and what they're saying my house is assessed at is totally wrong.

[Scarpelli]: So we've done our homework, and we reached out to the assessor, and the assessor has informed us that no one in his office has been involved in setting up any calculator for any organization to educate our community.

[Scarpelli]: So they know nothing about that.

[Scarpelli]: As a matter of fact, they also shared that the assessment team, our assessors,

[Scarpelli]: don't even understand how they can even conceivably work in an override if it was voted in in November because it's such a daunting task.

[Scarpelli]: So we asked, well, could you possibly put in place a calculator so residents can see what kind of an impact a true calculator through the assessor's office.

[Scarpelli]: He said no one's asked him to do that and he doesn't plan on doing it right now because they are so busy.

[Scarpelli]: And this is from the city's assessor.

[Scarpelli]: This is the city assessor.

[Scarpelli]: This is from the city assessor.

[Scarpelli]: So the understanding that it's just this much money, it's not.

[Scarpelli]: It's not.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that what I see as a trend that's bothering me is that our most vulnerable members of our community are threatened right now, and they should be.

[Scarpelli]: So if you're a senior citizen, you're living on a fixed income, if you are a veteran, if you are disabled, and you find it very difficult even just to survive right now,

[Scarpelli]: This could destroy them.

[Scarpelli]: Destroy them.

[Scarpelli]: And that's a realistic option.

[Scarpelli]: The misconception of some of my colleagues on the city council that

[Scarpelli]: Well, if the house is worth a million dollars, they could just take $100,000 out.

[Scarpelli]: And I share a story, and I won't give my neighbor's name because I love her.

[Scarpelli]: Let's call her Mrs. Jones.

[Scarpelli]: Mrs. Jones bought her house for $50,000 years ago with her and her husband, raised her family, lives there today.

[Scarpelli]: She was a seamstress.

[Scarpelli]: Well, Mrs. Jones' husband passed away 15 years ago, but the home is now appraised at a million dollars.

[Scarpelli]: With her social security and her husband's retirement, it's very difficult for Mrs. Jones to survive in her home because her home is being assessed.

[Scarpelli]: And just for taxes alone makes it very difficult for the choices she can make, whether it's eating something special during the week or paying for her medication.

[Scarpelli]: So people don't realize the impact, and it's true impact.

[Scarpelli]: uh... so i i think that's important as hundreds people hundreds of people in the city just like in a right there is i mean let's be honest that's a big part of it i mean so this is really going to affect everybody what i mean what if you rent well and i think that people don't realize that unfortunately you look at you look at some people like mrs jones same situation right that on the two or three family met for it uh... you would see that

[Scarpelli]: the trickle-down effect, where they can't afford to pick up the total cost that's being added to them, that they would have to put it onto their renters.

[Scarpelli]: And they don't want to.

[Scarpelli]: I will tell you, my dad was a homeowner of a two-family, and we took a lot of pride in making sure that our tenants

[Scarpelli]: were secure enough in the rent that they can maybe move forward and purchase a house.

[Scarpelli]: And we were lucky that we had five great tenants and four have moved on to own homes, and the fifth, my dad's moved on to heaven for a few years now, but my brother now owns the home and he still keeps that tenant's rent reasonable for them.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, the renters and, you know, you look at our tough students, they're going to be put in a bad situation as well.

[Scarpelli]: Because a lot of our tough students do rent, and that's going to impact them.

[Scarpelli]: Our small businesses, maybe you don't realize it, but when a family has to make a decision of just $400 or just X amount of dollars, they have to make cuts somewhere.

[Scarpelli]: And unfortunately, it's going to trickle down to our small businesses as well.

[Scarpelli]: And I think what people have to realize, too, because we've done some homework.

[Scarpelli]: I know that there are people on the other side that would like to say that there are organizations, like All Medford, who really have taken the leadership in this fight against the override because they see how it hurts most of the Medford residents.

[Scarpelli]: that they've done the homework, and we have communications back and forth.

[Scarpelli]: I know that one member has talked with the assessor again, and just so people understand that own homes, your homes have recently been assessed.

[Scarpelli]: So you can see that hike.

[Scarpelli]: Then you see taxes that might possibly be added on.

[Scarpelli]: Then you look at an override for a new high school that's going to be added on.

[Scarpelli]: the numbers from 2023.

[Scarpelli]: And why is that important?

[Scarpelli]: Our homes were assessed a lot higher in 2023 than they are today.

[Scarpelli]: So you're going to see a bump again in people's taxes.

[Scarpelli]: And it's funny that people that, you know, might not understand this because they don't own a home yet, but what they need to understand is that

[Scarpelli]: When the homes, they say in Medford, we're taxed low, and we are.

[Scarpelli]: We're very fortunate that our homes are taxed low.

[Scarpelli]: What they don't realize, the neighboring communities they want to compare us to.

[Scarpelli]: Because we heard nothing of an agreement.

[Scarpelli]: Then we move forward to what we're seeing, and we hear that there was a financial task force that was created

[Scarpelli]: right after that agreement.

[Scarpelli]: So we didn't know what was going on.

[Scarpelli]: We never had any public meetings.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't see any minutes.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't see any notes.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't get any updates of any financial team working together and what direction we're going into.

[Scarpelli]: So we fast forward to the meetings roughly around in May, and we can look at the meetings in May and June.

[Scarpelli]: We had discussions with Council President Bears, and I said, when are we hearing this information?

[Scarpelli]: When is a community going to get involved and be part of this financial task force results?

[Scarpelli]: And the question was, we came to results, and we'll be notified, and everybody will be informed in a meeting.

[Scarpelli]: I said, okay.

[Scarpelli]: Well, in typical fashion, on Thursday or Friday, we get an email from the mayor's office and her communications team, and they come out with an announcement that the financial task force has worked diligently to find the alternative solution for our gap in our financial crisis.

[Scarpelli]: At the time, it was $5 million coming from the school side.

[Scarpelli]: And what the financial team expressed on a Friday

[Scarpelli]: presented on a Tuesday was an override and dead exclusions to bring us whole.

[Scarpelli]: Now why is that frightening?

[Scarpelli]: that meeting I had put in place an option that Medford had over 24 million dollars of free cash.

[Scarpelli]: And for those people who don't know what free cash is, free cash is the money that is certified through the state that the city is approved for the budget that year.

[Scarpelli]: So

[Scarpelli]: Let's say, just for discussion's sake, let's say the budget was $10 million and you only spend $8 million.

[Scarpelli]: Well, that $2 million gets carried over into an account, what's called free cash, which is the taxpayer's money that was supposed to be used for the citizens and the community that fiscal year.

[Scarpelli]: Normally you see communities, but I think you'll see between 3 and 5 percent of an overage that carries over and then goes into that free cash account.

[Scarpelli]: Okay.

[Scarpelli]: Well, in Medford you saw an astronomical number that brought us for the last few years up to $24 million.

[Scarpelli]: So I came forth with an option.

[Scarpelli]: a pretty logical option that said, well, let's take that $5 million out of free cash, let's create a rainy day account, take $5 million out, let's level fund the school department so we eliminate any fear and confusion to our teachers, our students, and our educational process.

[Scarpelli]: And as I was presenting that, one of my council colleagues decided that they were going to call what we call in our rules is Rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: Rule 21 stops any discussions for that Councilor for that week, and you can follow it up the next week.

[Scarpelli]: Well, the reason why that was important, we knew that the next week the mayor was going to come in and present the budget.

[Scarpelli]: So they halted me from doing that, and then as we moved on, we moved on to the next meeting, but the next meeting, there was a meeting between the next meeting,

[Scarpelli]: I was going to come in as we were presenting this and I was going to stop the meeting and use rule 21 so we can ask can we have public meetings, a public participation, be more transparent about what the financial task force did, what are the numbers, who did you work with, what financial minds did you work with.

[Scarpelli]: went to the meeting, the city council leadership decided to suspend the rules and impose the freezing of the option to use rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: That means I couldn't stop the meeting.

[Scarpelli]: That means everything was pushed through.

[Scarpelli]: We had a free cash $5 million solution.

[Scarpelli]: They didn't want to hear it because the so-called financial task force came up with a $7.5 million override.

[Scarpelli]: No.

[Scarpelli]: As a matter of fact, it was the total opposite.

[Scarpelli]: And what's important, people saying, no, no, the audit, we already do an audit.

[Scarpelli]: Why should we pay anybody else to do an audit?

[Scarpelli]: Not true.

[Scarpelli]: The audit that comes in that we do every year is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: The person, the group that comes in and does the audit, they look at apples to apples.

[Scarpelli]: They say you start with 10 million, you spent 10 million, done.

[Scarpelli]: With the state audit, it comes in and it looks at the processes.

[Scarpelli]: So they could tell us, as you look at the process, if the council voted on it and the mayor approved it, you could then see how did we get here and what mistakes we've been making over the last few years because we consistently have millions of dollars of free cash.

[Scarpelli]: So that's voted down.

[Scarpelli]: It's voted down, city council votes it down, so we can't move forward.

[Scarpelli]: I did talk to, uh, to, uh, Mr. DiRico and they are in full support of finding other mechanisms to make, to bring this program, uh,

[Scarpelli]: and make it whole again in the future.

[Scarpelli]: I think that being that it isn't part of our agreement, it is a Tufts University policy that they're trying to really move forward.

[Scarpelli]: I know that what he did mention that it is one person from Medford.

[Scarpelli]: And one thing that I was happy about that those people that are enrolled right now will still have the full scholarship,

[Scarpelli]: and we'll finish the program in whole.

[Scarpelli]: So that's a piece that I thought was very important.

[Scarpelli]: But again, some of the people that were enrolled are, I think New Bedford, he mentioned some people out of the country, out of state.

[Scarpelli]: So it's a very diverse group that Tufts offers this program, but you do come across, as he said, Tufts University would love to do everything, but with the process and understanding

[Scarpelli]: paid tuition, free tuition, and finding that balance.

[Scarpelli]: I think that's what Tufts is really trying to find to make sure that this moves forward.

[Scarpelli]: So, again, I don't, what I, the message I received from Morocco is that they are, they will look high and low to make sure that this will continue, but it definitely needs a pause right now.

[Scarpelli]: so they can come back on stronger footing.

[Scarpelli]: So, um, and like again, I said, I know that there is one person from Medford and my biggest fear was if we're cutting this program with that person, not be able to fill what they started.

[Scarpelli]: And he said, absolutely not there.

[Scarpelli]: Everybody that's in the program right now.

[Scarpelli]: We can, yep.

[Scarpelli]: Yes.

[Scarpelli]: Yes, Councilor Bears.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you so much.

[Scarpelli]: And I very well put Councilor Callahan, but to further to expound on the free cash is the essential, the amount of money communities have over-budgeted.

[Scarpelli]: And according to the Mass General Department of Revenue, free cash represents the amount of community funds that are unrestricted and avail of appropriation.

[Scarpelli]: For example, the city of Medford has not had a city solicitor for many years.

[Scarpelli]: So that money would carry over year after year.

[Scarpelli]: Every year a salary from the city solicitor includes annual budget, because no one is receiving the salary.

[Scarpelli]: The amounts of that, if we put aside, city solicitor's salary goes into the city's free cash reserve for the city administration, the mayor, to use as they please if they need so.

[Scarpelli]: So how does the community use its free cash?

[Scarpelli]: Cities and towns in Massachusetts use free cash after it's certified.

[Scarpelli]: The Mass Department of Revenue is responsible for certifying free cash.

[Scarpelli]: After a city or town submits its financial information to the Department of Revenue, a community will receive its notification, the total amount of free cash, which is certified, therefore available for appropriation.

[Scarpelli]: Well, does Medford have free cash?

[Scarpelli]: Yeah, we do.

[Scarpelli]: Medford has free cash.

[Scarpelli]: As of September 10th, we were looking at a total of about $34 million.

[Scarpelli]: This is certified free cash, which means it's available to use.

[Scarpelli]: And especially in crises when you talk about underfunding a $5 million deficit in the school department, that's what that money could be used for.

[Scarpelli]: And then with the vision of financial minds working together to see if there are other avenues that we should use other than overrides, I feel it would be prudent for our community.

[Scarpelli]: So most communities, the four and 5% that's been mentioned, most communities,

[Scarpelli]: you see a two to maybe $3 million of free cash after every budget year.

[Scarpelli]: Now, you've consistently seen with this administration an absurd amount of money going into free cash because revenues were under projected.

[Scarpelli]: And maybe that's done for a reason, or maybe not.

[Scarpelli]: It's something that we would love to know with more transparency.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, this community, our community, our leadership team,

[Scarpelli]: haven't done that.

[Scarpelli]: So it leads us down a very, very slippery slope and it's dividing this community.

[Scarpelli]: So while we have the free cash and have the opportunity to not put the fear mongering into the community about teacher cuts or school issues or our children, why not use the free cash and eliminate those fears and then sit down like we talked about in the past where I was shut down by this council to look at a more, um,

[Scarpelli]: transparent, open form of participation to see where we need to do these three things.

[Scarpelli]: One understanding how the city got to this financial situation to

[Scarpelli]: How are we going to fix it?

[Scarpelli]: And three, what are we doing never to see this ever again?

[Scarpelli]: And this council and this mayor and this administration haven't done that.

[Scarpelli]: So to ask for an override right now is just absolutely frightening, especially to the homeowners that are living on a fixed income that we're looking at possibly losing their homes.

[Scarpelli]: So in the same vein as my fellow councilor asked to vote for the override, I'm going to implore to our residents that

[Scarpelli]: This is two different cases, two different stories, and it's going to be important so people can understand the truth.

[Scarpelli]: And the truth is, the city has mismanaged its budgets and mismanaged its organization in the city for years.

[Scarpelli]: And we see this with a $9 million certified free cash.

[Scarpelli]: That is unheard of, my friends.

[Scarpelli]: So yes, it is true.

[Scarpelli]: When you do take money out of free cash, it could possibly hurt your bond rating.

[Scarpelli]: But when you have $34 million, taking $5 million out to make sure our schools and our children have no fear of what might happen down the line, why wouldn't we do that?

[Scarpelli]: So thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Mr. President, if I can, I'm sorry.

[Scarpelli]: And that reads,

[Scarpelli]: incidental to related there too.

[Scarpelli]: So you'll vote no, because that's been a lot of people's questions.

[Scarpelli]: George, I thought you supported the firefighters.

[Scarpelli]: and how they've been treated.

[Scarpelli]: financially for an inferior product.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Danielle.

[Scarpelli]: Question seven is funding schools and street repairs.

[Scarpelli]: Shall the city of Medford be allowed to assess an additional 3.5 million in real estate

[Scarpelli]: and personal property taxes for FY25 general operations of the Medford Public Schools.

[Scarpelli]: to additional staff for road and sidewalk infrastructure repair for fiscal year beginning July 1, 2024.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Council President.

[Scarpelli]: If you'll allow me, over the past few years, I've heard many people talk about the legal claims or settlements or court judgments that have been paid by the city or school department for claims made against the city.

[Scarpelli]: the school department or employees of the city or the schools.

[Scarpelli]: Yet many of these claims and settlements that have been mentioned have never come before this council, either for an appropriation of money for payment or just to inform us about the claims.

[Scarpelli]: Going back to a time even before I was on the council, I know that the council had to approve the expenditures of any amount that was over $2,500.

[Scarpelli]: The purpose of this resolution is for the council to be made aware of the expenditures to settle or pay for various claims made against the city, the school, or any of our employees of the city or our schools.

[Scarpelli]: My motivation to bring this resolution forward is based on a very simple principle that I'm sure my colleagues can agree with.

[Scarpelli]: That is, expenditures of the city revenue is always a matter of accountability, transparency, and good government.

[Scarpelli]: People deserve to know where municipal dollars are being spent.

[Scarpelli]: With this in mind, I ask for the support of my colleagues on this resolution.

[Scarpelli]: Now, as we said tonight, I know that we mentioned just tonight, right?

[Scarpelli]: We said we need more funding, right?

[Scarpelli]: We need more funding.

[Scarpelli]: And we've seen over the last couple of months, we've seen a blatant financial mismanagement of our city's finances, as witnessed with the $9 million of free cash that was recently certified.

[Scarpelli]: The lack of new growth in our community over the past four years.

[Scarpelli]: Payments to outside councils that we still have yet to find what the true numbers are.

[Scarpelli]: And lastly, the settlements that mostly are unfunded by the city leadership.

[Scarpelli]: So this is very important because it's another aspect that week after week we're coming forward and that we're seeing mismanagement of our city funds.

[Scarpelli]: President Ferris.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: It's a sad day.

[Scarpelli]: when we heard the passing of probably one of the finest teachers to ever grace the hallways in the Medford Public Schools.

[Scarpelli]: Robin Irving was a very special person.

[Scarpelli]: She made it her life's mission to take care of our children.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's over 40 years of service, and Robin fought the fight against cancer and lost her battle.

[Scarpelli]: It's ironic that today's her 70th birthday, and I know that the family has put together a GoFundMe page to make sure her name carries on.

[Scarpelli]: in her name to scholarships for deserving children.

[Scarpelli]: So I wanted to mention that.

[Scarpelli]: She was an amazing person.

[Scarpelli]: I had many friends that had Ms.

[Scarpelli]: Irving, and when they talked about Ms.

[Scarpelli]: Irving, as if they had a mother out of their home, someone that took care of them.

[Scarpelli]: And then when I was,

[Scarpelli]: awarded the position to be a McGlynn Elementary Phys Ed teacher, I was honored to work on the other side of the door of Ms.

[Scarpelli]: Irving's.

[Scarpelli]: And if you ever went by Ms.

[Scarpelli]: Irving's room, you know that she was a teacher.

[Scarpelli]: She had everything she needed for every kid with every single lesson.

[Scarpelli]: And she was tough, there was times she was tough, but everybody respected her.

[Scarpelli]: And when we heard the sad news, I'm not less of a man to say, but I cried in my truck because she was one of the good ones.

[Scarpelli]: I know how much she loved them.

[Scarpelli]: And send our deepest condolences.

[Scarpelli]: This is a person that,

[Scarpelli]: you wanna name a library after, or you wanna name, leave someone's name to show their legacy, Robin Irving's the teacher that deserves that.

[Scarpelli]: President Bears?

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: The point of my resolution is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: This Councilman and I use the words transparency and accountability very often, and I do too.

[Scarpelli]: These words count.

[Scarpelli]: at the count only if we not only talk the talk, but we walk the walk.

[Scarpelli]: As this City Council is well aware, I submitted a letter to the Attorney General and the State Auditor's Office expressing my concerns over the way the City Council has used Rule 21 in Mass General Law, C-43, Section 22, unfairly and in a self-serving way to eliminate the discussion of resolutions that call for the expenditure of millions upon millions of dollars.

[Scarpelli]: When papers from the mayor were before the city council on June 7th, the council suspended the rules and approved the motion that the council rule 21 not be allowed to be invoked.

[Scarpelli]: Then on June 25th, my request to invoke Mass General Law C-43, section 22, which allows any one council to postpone consideration of a paper for one week was ruled out of order.

[Scarpelli]: At both of those meetings, my hope was that we could have an appropriate amount of time to discuss these significant issues and also receive input from our residents.

[Scarpelli]: When the council leadership ruled my request out of order, I had no choice but to bring this to the attention of the proper state offices to receive their input.

[Scarpelli]: The state auditor's office responded to me quickly.

[Scarpelli]: and reviewed my requests and explained first the requirements of the majority of the city council and the agreement of the mayor to move forward.

[Scarpelli]: So here's the simple part.

[Scarpelli]: If this council feels confident that its actions of those two meetings were correct, then your confidence in your actions can be reflected in your yes vote to allow this review.

[Scarpelli]: That would be true transparency and accountability.

[Scarpelli]: If however, you're not confident that the council's action were correct, you should still vote yes for this review because then we will have guidance from the state as opposed to an opinion bought and paid for by attorneys hired by the mayor.

[Scarpelli]: That would be true transparency and accountability.

[Scarpelli]: However, if you vote no on this resolution, it will show the residents of our city that this council uses the words transparency and accountability as a punchline that is empty and deceptive.

[Scarpelli]: Now is the time to stand up for what you say you believe in.

[Scarpelli]: let everyone know the only thing greater than your hollow words is your cowardice.

[Scarpelli]: So I will tell you, I will ask as a form of a motion that we vote to send this to be reviewed by the auditor, state auditor's office to look at our finances.

[Scarpelli]: Now, again, I'll say it publicly again.

[Scarpelli]: I have not one time mentioned

[Scarpelli]: that there is someone doing something illegal with the city's funds.

[Scarpelli]: My questions have been and stymied for one factor, one factor only, financial mismanagement.

[Scarpelli]: So I move that question, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Yes.

[Scarpelli]: Let me make it very clear then.

[Scarpelli]: In both the letter and in the resolution, I asked for examination on everything possible, period.

[Scarpelli]: So, I want the examination of our city finances, and I'll be meeting tomorrow with the Attorney General's office and talking about the legalities of the processes we have here.

[Scarpelli]: So, it's funny, Mr. President, that my fellow Councilors mentioned some pretty outrageous comments, like as this was something that wouldn't happen.

[Scarpelli]: This happened.

[Scarpelli]: The last four meetings,

[Scarpelli]: Maybe you don't have YouTube, but Councilor Lennon made sure everybody knows.

[Scarpelli]: Our meetings are on YouTube now.

[Scarpelli]: Watch those meetings.

[Scarpelli]: It's funny, Councilor Collins.

[Scarpelli]: You tell me about working together and council rules.

[Scarpelli]: And it's funny that you talk about disagreements.

[Scarpelli]: Of course we've had disagreements.

[Scarpelli]: And of course we sat across an issue and one lost and one won.

[Scarpelli]: Of course they did.

[Scarpelli]: But never, ever, ever has a sitting council been silenced the way this council has silenced me.

[Scarpelli]: no different than Councilor Callahan speaking about, it seems to fit the narrative whenever it suits your mission.

[Scarpelli]: But I remember when we had an issue concerning a legality dealing with a newsletter, and I said something very simple in regards also to the letter that was sent out to the state regarding the transfer tax.

[Scarpelli]: We don't have a city solicitor.

[Scarpelli]: I made a motion that we ask for an opinion from our legal team here.

[Scarpelli]: And I believe you voted no.

[Scarpelli]: And I believe all of you voted no.

[Scarpelli]: And that stymied the talk.

[Scarpelli]: That stymied the process that you yourself just said.

[Scarpelli]: So when you sit back and you start talking and you're spewing to the public that this is divisive, that this isn't true, oh, these are all true.

[Scarpelli]: These aren't made up.

[Scarpelli]: You suspended the rules so rule 21 could not be invoked.

[Scarpelli]: We were talking about millions and millions of dollars that this council got on a Friday and voted on a Tuesday.

[Scarpelli]: Is that what you talk about transparency and accountability?

[Scarpelli]: No.

[Scarpelli]: And instead of walking it through with this open, deliberate conversation, as you just well stated, we did it.

[Scarpelli]: We shut it down.

[Scarpelli]: We disrespected this councilor and my ability to work for not the 7,000 people,

[Scarpelli]: Not for the 7,000 people that elected you when you knocked on their doors, but when I put my hand up and I swore to uphold the rules and regulations and laws of this city, I represent all 60,000 members of this community.

[Scarpelli]: So to sit back and spew this disingenuine dialogue that these are lies, that what I'm saying is mistruths, these are situations risen on the fact that you, as the leadership team of this council, you stymied the process of open discussion.

[Scarpelli]: You did.

[Scarpelli]: If you remember the conversation and if you remember the dialogue that was set forth in my motions,

[Scarpelli]: was the fact that we had a financial task force that we didn't see or understand how they got to that situation.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't see how they showed us why we need an override, what got us to that override, and what are we gonna do in the next steps to make sure that we don't need another override the following year.

[Scarpelli]: These are the questions.

[Scarpelli]: This is a transparent process that we were asking for that evening.

[Scarpelli]: And of course people came up and voted for it.

[Scarpelli]: And of course they want to be told that we should go on to vote.

[Scarpelli]: Sure.

[Scarpelli]: But you're not listening to the people that are right in front of you.

[Scarpelli]: As many of those people that came up and said, we're for it, thank you so much.

[Scarpelli]: You have the same amount of people that are telling you right now.

[Scarpelli]: You're not listening to them.

[Scarpelli]: But you're not hearing them.

[Scarpelli]: when we had the opportunity before the votes came out and understood, okay, the financial task force met.

[Scarpelli]: no minutes, no understanding how they got to where they did, but we're gonna come out with a $7.5 million override, a $30 million debt exclusion, which by the way, you're gonna be shocked when the firefighters come knocking pretty soon, and the understanding that not just a week later, we find $9 million more in free cash.

[Scarpelli]: That alone, if that doesn't open your eyes and say, well, geez, Councilor Scarpelli, eliminate all the negative banter, eliminate one side or the other, geez, that's exactly what happened.

[Scarpelli]: And yeah, maybe we should look at that.

[Scarpelli]: Even though, Councilor Tseng said it, you just said it, people came to that podium.

[Scarpelli]: Of course they were in favor of it.

[Scarpelli]: But the problem was the people that had questions weren't listened to.

[Scarpelli]: That's a lack of transparency and accountability, my friend.

[Scarpelli]: This is the problem we have.

[Scarpelli]: This is why we're here.

[Scarpelli]: So you might be confused in the verbiage that I'm sending the auditor, but let me simplify it.

[Scarpelli]: I'm asking the auditor, with our vote,

[Scarpelli]: to look at our city's finances, period.

[Scarpelli]: We'll move forward with the Attorney General after I speak with them tomorrow.

[Scarpelli]: Maybe they have something to share.

[Scarpelli]: But this isn't a very difficult, you can make this a convoluted resolution and be very confusing just because you wanna sign it, but it's a very, to everybody, it's a very simple process.

[Scarpelli]: My resolution states that we ask the state auditor by a city council vote and then the mayor's approval

[Scarpelli]: to come in and look at the city's finances because I question the process of millions of dollars in free cash and the process of how we got to certain votes when it comes to a financial task force that didn't have minutes to explain to the public what's happened to this community financially, period.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Vice President Collins.

[Scarpelli]: What happens if the override fails?

[Scarpelli]: Council Bear stated, it'll be absolutely devastating.

[Scarpelli]: Donna, are you there?

[Scarpelli]: Eileen?

[Scarpelli]: Eileen, I'm requesting to unmute you.

[Scarpelli]: that use our tax money and pay them to do an audit to be very transparent and put everything to rest.

[Scarpelli]: And I think everyone would just like that.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Council President, if I can, just to clarify.

[Scarpelli]: If I can.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: I know that we've talked about the audit that's done every year.

[Scarpelli]: The process that, the piece that we really would benefit from, from the state audit, isn't just, the audit that we get every year is the figure, the money line.

[Scarpelli]: And it comes out, like I said, I don't question

[Scarpelli]: whether it's being used fraudulently in the sense that it's illegal.

[Scarpelli]: My questions I have, and something that the state auditor's office will do, is audit the process.

[Scarpelli]: Not only the figure, but the process.

[Scarpelli]: And that's what we're seeing with being the biggest issue right now.

[Scarpelli]: Because the audit comes in and they say, yep, all the numbers add up when you add up the numbers.

[Scarpelli]: But when the year is over, when the year is over and the mayor presents $9 million,

[Scarpelli]: The process has to be investigated.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you.

[Scarpelli]: This council might've known, but the financial team, they definitely knew there was $9 million.

[Scarpelli]: So first I want to commend the neighbors and the residents that really pulled together.

[Scarpelli]: And what you see in front of you is what happens when you see that something might affect our neighborhood in a negative way.

[Scarpelli]: What I found amazing is I went to an organization, a group of neighbors put together a meeting at the Fireman's Club, and I think probably about 130 people showed up.

[Scarpelli]: And what we heard from everybody there with respect and honor to every individual involved was that nobody was against the process of helping people.

[Scarpelli]: But what everybody was looking for is making sure that this facility or a facility like this would be put in a location where it didn't affect residential neighborhoods.

[Scarpelli]: It's amazing to see the community rally around this and really start a grassroots quick organization to really rally around and just educate people.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that's what's important.

[Scarpelli]: I think that we have, what I realized in those conversations, there were some people very angry at George Scapelli.

[Scarpelli]: and deservedly so.

[Scarpelli]: I think this is something that we talked about with our leadership team here that when we did the recodification of our zoning and we implemented these type of facilities in the medical field, in the zoning process, that it was then going to go to a special permit.

[Scarpelli]: We realized the impact it could have now legally

[Scarpelli]: with the facility like a methadone, and people keep saying clinic.

[Scarpelli]: And what really brought a lot of people to their feet was it's not a clinic.

[Scarpelli]: There weren't people there to assist people that were addicted, but it was just a distribution site.

[Scarpelli]: And

[Scarpelli]: We had people that were involved that were both former recovering addicts, and we talked to administrators in the field, and they really shared an input that really educated a lot of people.

[Scarpelli]: And again, at the end of the discussion, it wasn't that, let's keep these people out of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: No, it was, if it's needed in Medford, let's find a location where

[Scarpelli]: they can get their help and the support, but at the same time not affect a residential area that's.

[Scarpelli]: Feeds away from a dance studio, a school, the lack of parking in that area affecting small businesses.

[Scarpelli]: So there were a lot of little intricacies that played a huge part in what that neighborhood, the effects it would have had in the Salem Street neighborhood.

[Scarpelli]: I commend the mayor.

[Scarpelli]: I think that I had some issues because we wanted to make sure that without a city solicitor, I reached out to the mayor this weekend.

[Scarpelli]: She had an attorney that's well-versed in these topics to call me to make sure that we didn't say something that would get us in trouble later.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that with this motion,

[Scarpelli]: And as this process started moving forward, you saw that everybody was listening.

[Scarpelli]: You saw that every department in the city was listening.

[Scarpelli]: Any facilities under this criteria are moved into non-residential areas where it won't affect our residents.

[Scarpelli]: I will do this with all the papers tonight, but as my right, I'm invoking state law under Chapter 43, Section 22, which reads, Section 22, any ordinance or order or resolution may be passed through all stages of legislation at one session, provided that no member of the Council objects thereto.

[Scarpelli]: If any member of the council objects, the measure shall be postponed for that meeting.

[Scarpelli]: So I'm going to vote that right for the fact that we're pushing things through and we're not getting the information, at least this council is not getting the information they want.

[Scarpelli]: And it's a tactic that's very silly that we're going to try to get information that was passed, that was information that was given to me.

[Scarpelli]: If this is invoked, our ordinance is invoked, then I can supersede that with the state ordinance until I, as one city council,

[Scarpelli]: who finds this process so faulty, and so smelling with the lack of transparency, that we're so confused of where this money is coming from,

[Scarpelli]: and I've used this many, many times.

[Scarpelli]: I'm not saying anybody's doing anything illegal.

[Scarpelli]: I'm telling you this is financial mismanagement.

[Scarpelli]: We asked for a $7.5 million override on the fare of our families and children.

[Scarpelli]: I wanted to propose a $5 million free cash proposal that eliminate that fare, then the community can look to see whether we need an override or not, which I wouldn't oppose.

[Scarpelli]: But instead, we required it.

[Scarpelli]: I was stifled.

[Scarpelli]: So we would take that gamble.

[Scarpelli]: So that's what we did.

[Scarpelli]: I'll revert back to June 20th of last year during the budget meeting, when I'm sure you remember the meeting that you had with both Councilor Bears and President Morell.

[Scarpelli]: And as Councilor Bears stated before, it's in the minutes, it's in the video that Councilor Bears met with

[Scarpelli]: behind closed doors.

[Scarpelli]: And you came to an agreement and he's going to vote for the budget.

[Scarpelli]: And what we did was you sold your soul because what you did is I felt like Nostradamus because as I said that night, what you're doing is going to put our city and financial ruins.

[Scarpelli]: And here we are.

[Scarpelli]: And here we are.

[Scarpelli]: So the fact that when we look at where we are today,

[Scarpelli]: and what we talked about back a year ago, we've had one year knowing that this was gonna happen and what was created to make this less harsh for our community.

[Scarpelli]: Let's think about it.

[Scarpelli]: You started a financial task force of you, the chief of staff, Council President Bears, Councilor Collins,

[Scarpelli]: I believe vice chair Graham and the chief of staff.

[Scarpelli]: That is our financial team.

[Scarpelli]: When I talked to neighbor communities as they lunged into these proposition two and a half, I talked to Mayor Curtatone, who informed me back in 2009 when they faced the same situation.

[Scarpelli]: And this is what neighbor communities do for, I believe the word's been thrown out there, transparent, which I think is an absolute farce being used that way.

[Scarpelli]: What they did back in 2009 to that community, they set up a financial advisory committee provided with expert advice from both savings and revenue production measures designed to help the city maintain its financial strength and face this deepening economics recession.

[Scarpelli]: They looked at a committee which had Samuel Tyler, president of the Boston Municipal Research Bureau of Free Assistance, Jonathan Sloan, the president and co-CEO of Century Bank, Jeffrey Hartigan, senior vice president investments of UBS Financial Services, the Chamber of Commerce and leadership team from their financial team, and

[Scarpelli]: Daniel Richards, Professor Daniel Richards at Tufts University and in the economics department.

[Scarpelli]: That's what I've been saying, that we might need an override.

[Scarpelli]: We might need it.

[Scarpelli]: Why gamble our future, our kids' future, by not doing it properly?

[Scarpelli]: And what do we do?

[Scarpelli]: We met behind closed doors.

[Scarpelli]: Of course, when I asked for debt exclusion, I worked with the best financial mind in Aleesha Nunley.

[Scarpelli]: You remember her.

[Scarpelli]: Aleesha Nunley, who was an award-winning budget creator,

[Scarpelli]: she was, and when she broke it down for us, we eliminated senior citizens, and we eliminated veterans to see what that exclusion looked like for new fire stations.

[Scarpelli]: And the numbers were drastically different, but we were making sure we were taking care of the most vulnerable members of our community.

[Scarpelli]: What I asked for the other day was, when I was unceremoniously ruled 21,

[Scarpelli]: and made quiet again, because what I was saying made sense.

[Scarpelli]: Taking that money, five to $7 million out of free cash, and balancing the budget, and then working together by being more transparent and open in the process of an override.

[Scarpelli]: You mentioned that the process, that looking at the process, it's only $440 a year.

[Scarpelli]: Now, that's minimal.

[Scarpelli]: Sure, that sounds great.

[Scarpelli]: We talked about a debt exclusion for a fire station.

[Scarpelli]: That's probably $250 million debt exclusion for a new high school.

[Scarpelli]: Who does that fall on?

[Scarpelli]: Now their home's worth a million dollars.

[Scarpelli]: dispositions of all items appearing on the city council agenda.

[Scarpelli]: All items of business appearing upon council agenda shall be taken up in the order their parents and fully openly debates the disposal of by vote of council previous to the consideration of any other item of business.

[Scarpelli]: No item of business shall be referred to committee except for the following reasons.

[Scarpelli]: for the study and the report of subsequent meeting, for the purpose of drafting an ordinance, and the event that open discussions may prove damaging to the character and reputation of a person or persons, all matters referred to the committee shall reappear on the council agenda for the meeting for four weeks following the referral, unless sooner presented by the committee chair or a majority not exceeding two weeks is voted by the council upon request of the committee chair.

[Scarpelli]: majority committee memberships.

[Scarpelli]: Any financial paper appearing on the council agenda for the first time shall be automatically laid on the table for one week when such action is requested by any member.

[Scarpelli]: Now you might've suspended the rules, but I want the community to realize you stifled me last time disrespectfully shutting down rule 21 because I made sense.

[Scarpelli]: I think if we put a city with, you know, the council with partnership with the city solicitor or their designee,

[Scarpelli]: I think providing funding differently opens up another concern that we hear over and over again is in the community is where are where is all of our legal money going and what we're seeing even with our

[Scarpelli]: Our warrants, it's more than, for what I've counted so far, it's over $400,000.

[Scarpelli]: But thank you for all your hard work.

[Scarpelli]: Councilor.

[Scarpelli]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Scarpelli]: So the previous resolution that I voted no on, and I'll probably vote no on this.
