[Scarpelli]: He writes, I'm writing to formally resign from my position as Superintendent of Water and Sewer for the City of Medford effective April 5th, 2024.

[Scarpelli]: It is with heavy heart that I submit resignation as I've greatly appreciated the opportunities and experience I've gained in my time serving the City of Medford during my tenure.

[Scarpelli]: I have had the privilege of working under the leadership of DPW Commissioner Tim McGiven.

[Scarpelli]: I must commend Commissioner McGiven for his professionalism, dedication, and unwavering commitment to the betterment of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: His leadership has been a source of inspiration and guidance to me, and I am truly grateful for the support and mentorship he has provided.

[Scarpelli]: I will strive to emulate his exemption leadership as I move forward.

[Scarpelli]: Despite the admirable qualities Commissioner McGiven have found myself increasingly frustrated with the administration's lack of action addressing critical issues within the department.

[Scarpelli]: The recent handling supervisor of water and sewer job posting, coupled with the

[Scarpelli]: And something offers 0% costs of living increase for FY 24 has underscored and concerning absence of values you place in my position as well as the lack of priority place in the central matters, such as water main replacements, aging utility infrastructure staffing shortages and overall neglect.

[Scarpelli]: of the needs of the DPW.

[Scarpelli]: I have worked tirelessly to address compliances issues, modernize departmental operations to highlight the pressing concerns surrounding the water distribution system.

[Scarpelli]: Regrettably, my pleas for assistance recognition of regulatory concerns and urgent calls for action seemingly fallen on deaf ears.

[Scarpelli]: It is disheartening to feel ignored and undervalued in the position where the welfare of the community is at stake.

[Scarpelli]: I believe that my efforts have made this positive impact, but there is still so much work to be done.

[Scarpelli]: I have reached a point where I feel I have exhausted all avenues and effected meaningless change within the covered environment.

[Scarpelli]: It is essential that the City refocuses its attention on critical infrastructure projects, staffing needs, and operational improvements to ensure the continued well-being of Medford and its residents.

[Scarpelli]: I'm deeply concerned the residents are unaware of the alarming conditions of the water system and its critical need for substantial improvement.

[Scarpelli]: Immediate focus and drastic change are essential to ensure the integrity of Medford water infrastructure

[Scarpelli]: as time is running out.

[Scarpelli]: I'm grateful for the opportunity to have served the city of Medford and valuable lessons I've learned along the way.

[Scarpelli]: I extend my deepest appreciation to all those who have supported and collaborated with me during my time here as those contributions have been instrumental in shaping my professional growth.

[Scarpelli]: I wish the city of residence the best in the future and hope necessary steps will be taken to address the challenging challenges facing DPW.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you once again the opportunity to have been part of this community

[Scarpelli]: This is from residences dear method city council, I'm unable to make tonight's meeting live or on zoom due to conflict, I want to express my thoughts.

[Scarpelli]: on tonight's real estate tax proposal.

[Scarpelli]: I understand the issue of affordable housing and the need to address this issue.

[Scarpelli]: Maybe tonight's meeting will raise more awareness to our affordable housing needs in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: I for one will certainly pay more attention to this issue.

[Scarpelli]: I'm a lifetime resident of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: I raised my family here and went to Medford public schools and have contributed to the community in many ways.

[Scarpelli]: In fact, that's what I'm doing tonight.

[Scarpelli]: I think what's missing in this whole issue is the fact that there are thousands of different scenarios that homeowners have been planning for sales of their homes.

[Scarpelli]: Many people I know are thinking of their home as an asset for retirement.

[Scarpelli]: As we all know the cost of living and the cost of health care in this area are tremendously expensive.

[Scarpelli]: Some have leveraged their homes values to offset the college education of the children.

[Scarpelli]: Others were hit with illness and sent them in a different direction in life and thus the need for this asset is paramount to living a normal life in the city.

[Scarpelli]: I know this from experience.

[Scarpelli]: Most of us are not real estate moguls looking to make a fast buck.

[Scarpelli]: We're citizens who have worked hard our whole lives in this community.

[Scarpelli]: We deserve the right to use the sale of our home to make the right decisions for our families and our future in the city.

[Scarpelli]: So please do not derail the thousands of plans citizens have laid out for themselves by now blindsiding them with another tax.

[Scarpelli]: That's Jim McCarthy, 37 Blakely Road in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Okay, thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Again, I think that this is a very

[Scarpelli]: a hot topic.

[Scarpelli]: uh, responsible fiscal responsibility that's being maintained by administration.

[Scarpelli]: So these are things that I find still, um, a little concerning.

[Scarpelli]: Another piece that I, I received was that, you know, I, I, I'm not there right now, but I'm assuming there's at least one landscaper that's been in the city for a long time.

[Scarpelli]: I would assume he's there.

[Scarpelli]: Uh, but for the most part, our landscapers aren't really coming out and, um,

[Scarpelli]: you know, they're disgusted in the fact that they're just going to move away from Medford and the impact that this is playing on their part because, you know, they use they use leaf blowers.

[Scarpelli]: I mean, that's that's how they get through power through and make sure that they can keep homes affordable when you use a landscaper.

[Scarpelli]: So.

[Scarpelli]: I have a home, I'm going to use my electric blower, but I do it for what's needed and move on.

[Scarpelli]: But I just think there's a lot of variables.

[Scarpelli]: I know it sounds easy, and it's great to check off a box that we want to put in this ordinance, that it supports the environment, that it's really going

[Scarpelli]: you know, prepare our community later and moving in slowly into the phase out.

[Scarpelli]: But these are, these are difficult times and they're going to be worse in the future.

[Scarpelli]: And there's a lot of variables here that I can't support without, without more, um, more work being done to prove to me that this isn't going to be, this is going to be safer for the environment.

[Scarpelli]: So, um, I appreciate your time and thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Yeah, I just, I've done a little research on lithium batteries and, you know, uh,

[Scarpelli]: There is, you know, a huge, you know, question about them.

[Scarpelli]: When you're talking about lithium batteries and what they contain, the metals and cobalts and nickels and the contaminants, they contaminate water supplies and the ecosystem if they leach out of landfills, because that's how they're truly disposed.

[Scarpelli]: We could drop them off at Home Depot, but then they go to a landfill.

[Scarpelli]: And the biggest thing that we're hearing right now is what Officer McGover did say, is that they do cause a lot of fires.

[Scarpelli]: You're seeing that more and more as they're demanded more and more in our communities.

[Scarpelli]: I did do a little, I did do some homework on the lithium battery.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's something that as I get more involved with understanding, you know, our environmental needs and footprints, I think that, you know,

[Scarpelli]: The comparison that studies have shown is that we'll see more damage to our environment in the future, in the long run.

[Scarpelli]: The measurements can't be apples to apples, because this is something that's at its infancy.

[Scarpelli]: And you'll see it later in life.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that's what is keeping me from moving forward with this.

[Scarpelli]: And the particulates in the air,

[Scarpelli]: Bruni was a fixture, whether it was on the music site here in Medford, because he loved to dance and he loved to sing.

[Scarpelli]: You don't really make it until Bruno, until Bruni recognizes you.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that we so appreciate everything you do and I appreciate that you even had to come up here and share what you had to because there might have been some negative

[Scarpelli]: I'm glad you were here.

[Scarpelli]: I'm glad that we got it.

[Scarpelli]: We had a chance to speak, get the word out.

[Scarpelli]: And really, I think most importantly, is rally around as a council as an organization as a city to do more of these type of functions, because they're so important to what we're doing here.

[Scarpelli]: I mean, you want to talk about we have a room full of people that want to that are looking for true inclusion and peace and happiness.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that you're you're

[Scarpelli]: You're the originators.

[Scarpelli]: However, on October 7, Hamas terrorists violated the ceasefire and attacked

[Scarpelli]: kibbutzim, villages, and a music festival murdering 1,200 Israeli, including not only Jews, but Muslims, Christians, Jews, Americans, Thais, Russians, British, among others.

[Scarpelli]: While mutilating many bodies, burning some alive in ovens, and raping countless women, there were people ranging in ages eight to 87 years old.

[Scarpelli]: There was among over 230 kidnapped people that were brought back to Gaza, of which 136 are still being held.

[Scarpelli]: If they are alive, we still have questions.

[Scarpelli]: Since Hamas has not allowed the IRC to visit the hostages, we have no idea how any of them are doing.

[Scarpelli]: A ceasefire resolution only gives confidence to Hamas that they are winning the war in the West and makes it harder to get the hostages, the bodies, back.

[Scarpelli]: Plus, Israel will not accept a ceasefire unless includes a return of all hostages and bodies as well as leadership of Hamas being sent into exile to a country that will accept them.

[Scarpelli]: Unless those conditions happen, it doesn't matter how many cities or states or countries vote for a ceasefire.

[Scarpelli]: Israel will not accept it.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that whether you believe in it or not, these are messages that come from families of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: We have another that was sent

[Scarpelli]: that wanted to reach out in the statement.

[Scarpelli]: Forgive me that they're longer, but to members of the council and those in attendance, thank you for listening to this statement.

[Scarpelli]: The months since 10-7 have been extremely tight trying for the Jewish community.

[Scarpelli]: We experienced a predominantly attack on the brothers and sisters solely because they are Jewish.

[Scarpelli]: It brings back haunting memories of when this was commonplace not more than a century ago.

[Scarpelli]: We are slaughtered not for the military advantage, not for political maneuvering, but because we're Jewish.

[Scarpelli]: The only thing different today is that there is a country and an army that will push back and defend us.

[Scarpelli]: In the World War Two during the programs in Russia,

[Scarpelli]: and the inquisitions across Liberia and in ups or uprisings like Farhoud in Middle East, we were defenseless.

[Scarpelli]: But today in the first time in 2000 years, we have the ability to stand up and push back against the Jew haters that are attempting to alienate us.

[Scarpelli]: In the latest, we have experienced rapidly rising anti-Semitism, including here at home, with genocide chants down the street at Harvard, and anti-Zionists who, by definition, call the destruction of the Jewish homeland in Israel.

[Scarpelli]: We hear louder and louder every day the warning signals that Jews are no longer safe, coupled with the thousands upon thousands who celebrated our deaths on 10-7.

[Scarpelli]: We are scared.

[Scarpelli]: We cannot trust our local officials to stand against anti-Semitism, and we cannot trust our fellow citizens when we see them marching in the streets calling for more Jewish deaths.

[Scarpelli]: Our concerns are not heard.

[Scarpelli]: Our safety is ignored.

[Scarpelli]: And this ceasefire resolution before you is a symbol that you are telling Jews to once again not push back, not fight for the survival, but lay down and take it.

[Scarpelli]: That is what we hear when there are calls for Israel to call off the war against those who started this in the Battle of 10-7.

[Scarpelli]: During World War II, we did not have a ceasefire for Nazis or Imperial Japan, despite the horrific amount of civilian death in the war and aggression the Axis started.

[Scarpelli]: There was no ceasefire against Al Qaeda 9-11, and the worldwide Jewish community will not abide the ceasefire with the Hamas.

[Scarpelli]: The common thread here is that there cannot be a ceasefire

[Scarpelli]: with groups whose entire reason for existence is ideological mass murder.

[Scarpelli]: The only type of viable, long-term, and durable ceasefire is one where Hamas' war-making ability is destroyed.

[Scarpelli]: Only then can Israeli lives and security of the Palestinians can be free from an Islamic dictatorship.

[Scarpelli]: A ceasefire that leaves Hamas in place is a banned

[Scarpelli]: band-aid upon a cancer.

[Scarpelli]: It may save some lives in the short term, but guarantees more war, death, and destruction down the road.

[Scarpelli]: Hamas officials have promised to repeat the genocide of 10-7 again and again.

[Scarpelli]: Israel will be forced to continue to defend their citizens.

[Scarpelli]: Hamas will continue to try to kill Jews and hide behind their own Gaza subjects.

[Scarpelli]: Jews, Arabs, Israelis, Palestinians, all will suffer until Hamas is no longer

[Scarpelli]: poses a threat.

[Scarpelli]: I know it's a good start to have a facilities manager, but I would love to see what other communities have.

[Scarpelli]: I mean, most communities have a facilities manager that has an assistant manager that also has a facilities crew that does electrical.

[Scarpelli]: They have an electrician, a plumber, and a carpenter that's on staff that you're not wasting time or money bringing outside contractors to do things we need.

[Scarpelli]: in most cases at a minute's notice.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that that's how most facilities teams work in most communities.

[Scarpelli]: You know, I remember when Medford, the school department, used to have its own maintenance team.

[Scarpelli]: They had a locksmith, an electrician, we had a plumber, we had a carpenter, we had a painter, that they worked.

[Scarpelli]: And again, this is with the old schools, the neighborhood schools, that they kept them up as much as they could.

[Scarpelli]: But we're looking at what's so-called the new schools now that are now outdated and in desperate need of upgrades.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that

[Scarpelli]: having the new facilities manager come to us, and believe me, I don't expect the person to come up and say, yeah, this is what we need.

[Scarpelli]: I think we might have to look at asking the mayor to bring in a consultant that goes through the whole building, like Weston and Sampson, that other communities use, that go through all of our buildings and come through with the honest assessment of what we need in our priorities, starting high priority first.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you.

[Scarpelli]: I think that we've seen, Madam President, through the chair, I believe it's a

[Scarpelli]: I think that we're seeing our city engineer being more proactive when we're opening our streets to private entities, let's say a resident wanting to change from a lead pipe to copper water pipe.

[Scarpelli]: I believe the new policies in place now that the homeowner now has to pay the contractor to go curb to curb, which if what bothers me with that is that I don't know.

[Scarpelli]: There's still question, I think, to ask the city engineer that when the utilities come in,

[Scarpelli]: are they mandated for the same type of restoration?

[Scarpelli]: If they open the street from what I've been told, they're not.

[Scarpelli]: They open up the area that needs to be open that they can get to, they resurface it, they let it sit one cycle, and they come back and resurface it.

[Scarpelli]: But I think that's not fair.

[Scarpelli]: I think the basic resident, the homeowner, or, you know,

[Scarpelli]: The landlord that has to pay for the safer, you know, transfer of lead to copper has now

[Scarpelli]: bringing up the rate that's falling back on the consumer because now the contract is not saying, okay, let's keep it the same price.

[Scarpelli]: And what I do want to make sure that

[Scarpelli]: You have people that exercise their rights

[Scarpelli]: to go and work polls, and I'm reading the criteria, and I've been doing this since I was a little kid, neighboring communities, and understand that this is a process that's legally in place.

[Scarpelli]: And there's something even here that says that what people don't understand, what I'm speaking is poll workers, people that don't know that are watching.

[Scarpelli]: candidates have an opportunity to build a team to make sure they're working their team to most efficient process to make sure they get their voters out on election day.

[Scarpelli]: So people work very hard to set up these teams that at each polling location, they had what's called the poll watcher.

[Scarpelli]: And a poll watcher would sit in an approved area by law,

[Scarpelli]: they would, I know that it said that they're not to provide a chair or table, we understand that.

[Scarpelli]: We have here that this is the process.

[Scarpelli]: This is where we wanna help people feel comfortable and understand the process.

[Scarpelli]: And there's this part here that says they're not to sit down, even if they bring their own chairs.

[Scarpelli]: That's something I would question.

[Scarpelli]: Okay, I think that's terrible for the fact that it's exactly why we're here tonight for these little things.

[Scarpelli]: The understanding of educating our workers, the process of the new pads.

[Scarpelli]: Now, what we trained, because I was part of one of these teams, they were trained, the poll workers were trained to understand this.

[Scarpelli]: As a person comes in, they're asked for their ID or not.

[Scarpelli]: They were then asked for their name and address.

[Scarpelli]: Then they would say their name and they would repeat back their name and address.

[Scarpelli]: What we saw firsthand though, because I was there, what I saw was it would say, they would show their ID and then they'd go right through.

[Scarpelli]: It wasn't repeated in some cases.

[Scarpelli]: In some other cases, their names were given but they weren't repeated back.

[Scarpelli]: So the whole format was a mess.

[Scarpelli]: The way that poll workers that volunteered to come out, the way they were treated was horrible.

[Scarpelli]: So as we're moving forward to this process, now, whatever the process is, if it's just putting out the markers, where to stand on election day, because we didn't do that this year.

[Scarpelli]: Why?

[Scarpelli]: I don't know, but we didn't do that.

[Scarpelli]: So we had people at different locations moving anywhere they wanted.

[Scarpelli]: And you had some areas with some aggressive poll managers that are coming out.

[Scarpelli]: I forgot what we call them, but, and then we had other areas that we didn't have it.

[Scarpelli]: So it was inconsistencies.

[Scarpelli]: So the process in total, I'm reading this, and I'll be honest with you, I'm not truly satisfied because when some of these issues occurred with the ballots and who got what ballots and the misprinting of the ballots, we as a council found it to be a problem.

[Scarpelli]: We said, quote unquote, that perception is reality.

[Scarpelli]: And if we need to do anything, please, let's work as a team to figure out a way, whether it's approving money, whether it's hiring people, whether it's getting people educated, we didn't do that.

[Scarpelli]: Instead, we just ran with it.

[Scarpelli]: And it was exactly what we were afraid of.

[Scarpelli]: It was a mess.

[Scarpelli]: It was completely a mess.

[Scarpelli]: Then the process moves forward with people getting ballots that they shouldn't have.

[Scarpelli]: Then we have, we've corrected that.

[Scarpelli]: Then there was some ballots that, you know, that had the wrong dates and we corrected that.

[Scarpelli]: And then, then we go to the election day and there were multiple issues with people not understanding the process and how people were treated.

[Scarpelli]: Then you move after the election process and understanding that there were legal documents that were sent out saying, for instance,

[Scarpelli]: The mail-in ballots will be tabulated here at City Hall and posted at eight o'clock at City Hall.

[Scarpelli]: That was never done.

[Scarpelli]: Questions that people have asked.

[Scarpelli]: We talked about when it stopped, polling stops at eight, the voting stops at eight, and 8.30 things will be posted.

[Scarpelli]: Well, we didn't get posts, we didn't realize the final numbers until one o'clock in the morning.

[Scarpelli]: So these are all legitimate issues.

[Scarpelli]: And I read through this report, and it sounds great, but I think it needs more substance.

[Scarpelli]: Hello, everyone.

[Scarpelli]: I wanted to provide an update in the last email.

[Scarpelli]: The humanitarian crisis unfolding in our region.

[Scarpelli]: We believe the state is moving forward with the facility at 400 Riverside to serve as a temporary overnight shelter for families.

[Scarpelli]: My office, along with our Acting Building Commissioner, Fire Chief and Board of Health, Emergency Response Director, have outlined our concerns as well as our code requirements to ensure that the governor's administration ensures a safe and secure environment for families currently in the state's wait list

[Scarpelli]: for emergency assistance.

[Scarpelli]: I'm working toward reaching an MOU to set a clear limit on the number of people housed at the facility as well as capping the duration of each family's stay.

[Scarpelli]: The reasons being the facility is very large and could fit thousands because three of our elementary schools are already at capacity.

[Scarpelli]: My ask of that

[Scarpelli]: Schools are already capacity that this be for no more than 75 families, 250 people, which is what was the original plan for the state.

[Scarpelli]: The shelter is active until April or June, and the latest based on legislators, recent legislation, that the families rotate into permanent shelter within three to four days.

[Scarpelli]: Again, these are just my asks, and there are no specifics for report out of the public yet.

[Scarpelli]: To date there is no lease agreement in place with the owner of 400 Riverside, no contract with the health and services provider, and as I said, no MOU.

[Scarpelli]: in place with the city, so there are a few details that can be shared.

[Scarpelli]: As you may have read, the state is moving forward and has already opened the Cambridge site, which took priority.

[Scarpelli]: As soon as I am fully briefed by the state in specifics and operations terms upon Riverside, I will relay

[Scarpelli]: Excuse me, that info to you all as well as the public.

[Scarpelli]: So moving forward, I know that we'll have a new council, but I think as this council looks to move people forward and look at our budgetary processes, we have to start looking for people.

[Scarpelli]: If the city administration is not going to hold people accountable, then we're going to have to make sure that they

[Scarpelli]: that they know that this council is going to be strong enough to make sure they hold their people to the feet of the fire.

[Scarpelli]: Because this has been an absolute laughingstock across the commonwealth.

[Scarpelli]: And the fact, I'll be honest with you, I'm disgusted with the Secretary of State's office.

[Scarpelli]: Reached out to them, haven't heard anything.

[Scarpelli]: This is what they're all about.

[Scarpelli]: If this is what the Secretary of State and our governor sees that that's appropriate, look what's happening.

[Scarpelli]: It's a trickle-down effect.

[Scarpelli]: Now, who knows how many people aren't going to come out for the next elections.

[Scarpelli]: And why?

[Scarpelli]: No one's told us anything.

[Scarpelli]: No one's even talked to me.

[Scarpelli]: I got a bunch of fluffy, I'm getting a lot of emails, fluffy emails, you know, wishing me luck, a happy birthday, a congratulations, but no one is still from that commission's talked to me about, George, this is what's going on.

[Scarpelli]: And they're good people.

[Scarpelli]: And then for the recount, I know I wasn't there, but I,

[Scarpelli]: I talked to a few people that came here, gave their time to help with the process.

[Scarpelli]: And I heard our coordinator, our elections coordinator was verbally getting in people's faces and disrespecting people to the point where the attorney from the from the candidate side had to step in and say, Please do not address any of our people.

[Scarpelli]: Talk to me.

[Scarpelli]: That's a disgrace.

[Scarpelli]: Everybody's watching to see where the accountability pieces.

[Scarpelli]: That's what everybody's waiting to see.

[Scarpelli]: It says, temporary shelter.

[Scarpelli]: Hello, representatives, senators, members of Medford City Council, Medford School Committee.

[Scarpelli]: I wanted to give you all a heads up on an ever-evolving matter.

[Scarpelli]: At the end of last week, I was informed that 400 Riverside Ave was being explored.

[Scarpelli]: as a possible temporary winter emergency shelter for migrant families on the wait list.

[Scarpelli]: The state was only going to pick one site from my recollection on a phone call.

[Scarpelli]: The families would only each stay a few nights before they would be transitioned.

[Scarpelli]: The shelter was going to run through April and start with those families currently staying at 10 Park Plaza and may build up to no more than 75 families.

[Scarpelli]: He also said that this was the site they plan to try to move forward with.

[Scarpelli]: I have another call with the state tomorrow to try to get more clarity.

[Scarpelli]: you're allowed to have poll watchers, and it's a machine.

[Scarpelli]: So the poll watchers go out.

[Scarpelli]: It's a calculated strategy where they're allowed to have poll watchers sit in a relatively close area that you can hear and see the process.

[Scarpelli]: The process is very simple, that the poll watchers

[Scarpelli]: There was talk that they were told they can't sit down.

[Scarpelli]: Then they were told they can't sit down if they bring their own seats.

[Scarpelli]: And if that's the case, OK, bring your own seat.

[Scarpelli]: Pole watchers sat in their seats.

[Scarpelli]: And then they were told to move 25 feet away.

[Scarpelli]: And then the process was very simple.

[Scarpelli]: The process that by law states, in the general laws that we had attorneys pass out to each polling station, each warden, and it said straight out, the process is such, when the person approaches to vote, if they have a license or not,

[Scarpelli]: because we had the new scanning system.

[Scarpelli]: And believe me, I do not blame the poll, the workers that are at the poll, I don't blame them, because a lot of them are great people and they just weren't prepared, but they had the licenses.

[Scarpelli]: They have the license, you're supposed to sweep their name and address.

[Scarpelli]: They're supposed to say, George Scarpelli, 27 Butler Street, and the poll worker responds back, George Scarpelli, correct.

[Scarpelli]: for the purpose of clarity and transparency.

[Scarpelli]: And then what they do is that person has a book, same as the workers do, and they check off who comes in and votes.

[Scarpelli]: And then if you have a machine that works for you, volunteers that want to work for you, you then have people pick up those books every two to four hours.

[Scarpelli]: And then you have people in offices or at homes calling people and saying, hey, we see you haven't voted today.

[Scarpelli]: Do you need a ride?

[Scarpelli]: It's a machine.

[Scarpelli]: It's done all over the country.

[Scarpelli]: Conspiracy theories through the roof, and I'm not a conspiracy theorist, I hate it.

[Scarpelli]: And what happened this past week and the weeks before this and understanding how this process went was a disgrace.

[Scarpelli]: How much money did we lose?

[Scarpelli]: When you don't open up the boxes of the ballots to a few days before you have to mail out the mailing ballots, and you realize you have someone's name spelt wrong, so they have to be thrown away.

[Scarpelli]: Now you have to get ballots reprinted and rushed in, which is thousands of dollars.

[Scarpelli]: And then they go out and then we realize that we're getting phone calls from Ward 6 saying everybody that ordered, that requested four ballots got eight.

[Scarpelli]: Everybody that got asked for two got four.

[Scarpelli]: Everybody asked for three got six.

[Scarpelli]: And then we had to reassure the public that even though it looks bad, they cannot vote three to six times.

[Scarpelli]: And we said that day,

[Scarpelli]: And maybe if people lived like that a little bit more and understood that to be true, I think that it would stop a lot of animosity in our community.

[Scarpelli]: We're all together as Mustangs supporting our team.

[Scarpelli]: So, Nicole, I'll even buy a baby a nice little outfit, a little Mustang outfit.

[Scarpelli]: Chris, if you can.

[Scarpelli]: There was nothing better than listening to a group of Brazilian kids screaming defense while the offense was on the field.

[Scarpelli]: There was nothing better than that.

[Scarpelli]: We have other things we should celebrate, but we should be celebrating

[Scarpelli]: The fact that our marching band won the championship and came in this community, I love the fact that they had the police escorts come in.

[Scarpelli]: These are things we should be celebrating.

[Scarpelli]: We have so many great things.

[Scarpelli]: Thanksgiving is a good start.

[Scarpelli]: I have it right here for everybody.

[Scarpelli]: I see Councilor Scarpelli.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Council.

[Scarpelli]: I think that's what my sentiments were.

[Scarpelli]: I think that the biggest concern we had when this came in front of this body is that, especially at the time during the pandemic, we were seeing the effects, the negative effects with what was happening in our country affecting our brick and mortar businesses.

[Scarpelli]: And as we continue to work out of the pandemic, and here we are, we're finally safe, hopefully,

[Scarpelli]: We're seeing businesses thriving, especially in the square.

[Scarpelli]: I think the number one goal is not to allow

[Scarpelli]: the food trucks other than what we stipulated in the guidelines that Council Bears expressed that it was for special events.

[Scarpelli]: I think that, but the concern was that there are special events that come up and sometimes the council won't meet and it leaves organizations in limbo.

[Scarpelli]: So it's giving the right to city administration

[Scarpelli]: and the Board of Health to give that permission and take it off the City Council plate for those purposes.

[Scarpelli]: We don't want anybody to miss out on an opportunity, but at the same time, my number one goal from the beginning was protecting our brick and mortar businesses, especially in the climate that we're in right now here in Medford, where

[Scarpelli]: What we have, we need to keep and what we need to grow on the brick and mortar businesses.

[Scarpelli]: If we're bringing in food trucks from outside the city and allowing these organizations to roll up, we're going to really taint what we're looking for, and especially most of our squares and

[Scarpelli]: and bringing more solid businesses to the city of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: a food truck provision to come and go as they may please and take business away from what we need to grow in this community.

[Scarpelli]: that history and that pride of being an American citizen.

[Scarpelli]: company while going to Don Bosco High School to learn English because, as he said it, it was his honor to learn the language of the great country he moved to.

[Scarpelli]: For one, Councilor, I've had a serious issue with how the community, how this community, our leadership team, really puts together the vision of our growth and development plan.

[Scarpelli]: We say we have a comprehensive plan, but it is all over the place.

[Scarpelli]: To me, there are so many questions with this building.

[Scarpelli]: A, you're on probably one of the most busiest intersections, one of the biggest concerns of traffic in this community, huge issue.

[Scarpelli]: How many people do you plan on occupying this building on a day-to-day basis?

[Scarpelli]: Possibly 80, 100 people.

[Scarpelli]: And there's only 23 parking spots.

[Scarpelli]: It abuts a neighborhood.

[Scarpelli]: Can appreciate that.

[Scarpelli]: As you can see, there's no guarantee for any business.

[Scarpelli]: So if you last five to 10 years, the next business comes in and has no philosophy or belief in the same as you do.

[Scarpelli]: So again, it affects our community.

[Scarpelli]: Please don't take this personal, because I would love to find a location for this type of development.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's amazing.

[Scarpelli]: I think we've turned a few away that has really hurt us.

[Scarpelli]: But I think the biggest issue I see

[Scarpelli]: is we don't have a true development plan.

[Scarpelli]: You saw how it looks there.

[Scarpelli]: It looks out of place.

[Scarpelli]: It's a beautiful building, but it's out of place.

[Scarpelli]: You have a community of two to three family homes no more than 100 yards away from you.

[Scarpelli]: You're talking about an intersection that has been habitually taken advantage of.

[Scarpelli]: You're talking about a neighborhood that has felt that they have been

[Scarpelli]: they have been treated so unfairly and overlooked so many years.

[Scarpelli]: So there's a lot of variables that has nothing to do with you.

[Scarpelli]: So I want you to understand that.

[Scarpelli]: I think that when we talk about development and you look at the plan of Mystic Ave, man, I would love to see, I mean, the idea can be sold so easily when you're building

[Scarpelli]: four, five, six, 10 similar locations, all the way down Mystic Ave, where there's establishments to eat, go for a drink, go for shopping, to live.

[Scarpelli]: That's a community, right?

[Scarpelli]: That's a community building.

[Scarpelli]: And then when you're trying to sell the concept of 100 people in only 23 spots and thinking that now it's not gonna affect it, everybody's gonna drive a bike or a bus.

[Scarpelli]: We wish that could be the case, but that's not true.

[Scarpelli]: At least that's what the neighbors, the neighbors that we deal with every day in that community, you have to understand, they're scorned.

[Scarpelli]: They're part of this community that have been bypassed in many different levels.

[Scarpelli]: As I'm sitting here right now, I'm getting text messages of people that live right on that road that are disgusted that we're even talking about this.

[Scarpelli]: And it's a shame that, and I'll say it publicly, I think this is the concept, this is beautiful.

[Scarpelli]: That building is beautiful.

[Scarpelli]: You know, I think the idea of it, you know, when you see neighboring communities, like I'm sure you have, you see the assembly road, you see what's going on in Malden, you see what's happening in Everett, you're seeing this type of development grow together.

[Scarpelli]: But we have a unicorn sticking out of an eight-story unicorn sticking out of probably the most densely populated traffic area that we've had so many issues in the past.

[Scarpelli]: So I personally, not anything you did, but what this administration has done when we talk about development and growth, not having a true picture.

[Scarpelli]: If the city sat next to you, stood next to you,

[Scarpelli]: the development department sat with you, and they said, George, this is our plan, and this is what it's gonna look like.

[Scarpelli]: Because I sat with a gentleman years ago in a disgusting field in Somerville, and he opened this door, and he showed me this full life-size model of something called Assembly Row.

[Scarpelli]: And his vision was talking about gateway communities, talking about how when you enter Somerville, this is what it's gonna look like, this is what's gonna grow to this, this is what's gonna grow to that, and guess what?

[Scarpelli]: It's happening.

[Scarpelli]: Just this great little shop area now has buildings for health care, buildings for corporate development.

[Scarpelli]: It's grown.

[Scarpelli]: People, a tea stop right there.

[Scarpelli]: So of course you don't need parking there.

[Scarpelli]: And you see how crazy it is there now.

[Scarpelli]: So this is what we're not having in Metro.

[Scarpelli]: I just personally think that, you know,

[Scarpelli]: you're a catalyst to say, okay, here is the perfect development team that wants to come back and talk about Lincoln, talking about taking care of the community, talking about parking issues, talking about environmental issues, looking at the sciences, and let's use them as a catalyst to say, okay, this is gonna be here, and this is how we're gonna grow that area.

[Scarpelli]: if we vote this forward tonight, that can't be adjusted as it moves forward for all of the different hurdles that residents have to go through when they're looking to, I believe it was support a family member, not moving him or them to outside services or into housing, but they want to look to take care of their own

[Scarpelli]: on their own property and the property that they're requesting and without the burden to anybody else.

[Scarpelli]: I think that's valuable and I would still support it.

[Scarpelli]: So I have a motion on the floor, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: It's come to my attention that

[Scarpelli]: our turf fields are in disarray.

[Scarpelli]: And although we appreciate all the hard work going into all of these grant funded parks and playgrounds, I think our city administration has forgotten about the existing fields.

[Scarpelli]: And this is something that I've been putting on the agenda for years, hoping someone would listen.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, when I'm gathering from some parents, they're a little nervous, especially what's happening in Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: The field is a turf field.

[Scarpelli]: The field does have black pellets, but the field hasn't been tested for GMAX.

[Scarpelli]: Now what the GMAX study does is it should be tested every year, this is what we do in my profession, on a turf and natural surface fields to make sure the density is safe after a long period of time.

[Scarpelli]: The Field of Dreams was started back in early 2010.

[Scarpelli]: We're now coming on to 2024, and the life expectancy of a turf field that is maintained properly, that means to come in and groom it on a regular basis, that means on a yearly basis, coming in and doing a deep clean, that means taking the pellets up,

[Scarpelli]: re-grooming the surface and then re-entering the pellets, which, from what I gather, we haven't done on a consistent basis here in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: What was brought to my attention, the way I brought this up, is that as soon as someone says safety to me, I have to present it in a resolution so the city can get back to us in a timeline that

[Scarpelli]: God forbid somebody gets hurt and those tests weren't done, then the liability, and if the attorney's still here, this would be great because I know if the city solicitor were here, I know that that would be something very important to stress the fact that getting that test done.

[Scarpelli]: Again, what I request is the city administration to have a licensed turf

[Scarpelli]: contractor come in with a GMAC study for turf, not natural surface.

[Scarpelli]: They're two different tests.

[Scarpelli]: And they do a test at Edgley Fields behind the high school, the fields at Hormel Stadium, and from what I gather, the field at the Brooks School is absolutely deplorable.

[Scarpelli]: It's probably one of the most used playgrounds in the community.

[Scarpelli]: I know our school age kids at the Brooks love that field considering what they had years ago and the mud bowl that they used to have to and then bring it into the school and it started destroying the floors at the school.

[Scarpelli]: The community really put a good effort, but they forgot again.

[Scarpelli]: an existing playground and park and Metro completely forgotten.

[Scarpelli]: So.

[Scarpelli]: I would recommend, I would make the motion that we ask the city administration.

[Scarpelli]: I don't know if it falls under the facilities manager.

[Scarpelli]: Did we hire a facilities manager?

[Scarpelli]: So we have one.

[Scarpelli]: Maybe that facilities manager, because at least in my role, we have a facility manager that actually oversees the parks as well as the actual buildings.

[Scarpelli]: as soon as possible.

[Scarpelli]: Kids are on those fields today.

[Scarpelli]: what can happen later.

[Scarpelli]: realizing the fields that he was playing on caused the concussions, not the head butting, not the physical bump to bump, but the actual falling on the turf as a goalie onto a turf that wasn't tested properly.

[Scarpelli]: report back to us.

[Scarpelli]: to those fields, it's simple as this.

[Scarpelli]: Vacuum in the pellets, adding liquid nail down, patting it back down, and then putting a weight on top of it for 24 hours, and we don't have those dangerous issues anymore.

[Scarpelli]: And then re-entering the pellets.

[Scarpelli]: It's simple, but no one's doing it.

[Scarpelli]: because we didn't do the preventative maintenance that we typically haven't done in our facilities so far.

[Scarpelli]: So I hope that answers that.

[Scarpelli]: The vehicle is set to be moved from the school grounds on or about July 14th.

[Scarpelli]: In the past,

[Scarpelli]: With the explicit permission of the school department and buildings principal, school parking has been made available for use by individual Medford residents, other city departments, including the Department of Public Works and Public Safety Department, public and private contractors for temporary parking of construction machinery and other entities and organizations, including film crews working in the city of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: the school parking space will not in any way impede or interfere with student employee or public access to school facilities.

[Scarpelli]: You know, it's funny when things go out, and the discussion was that they're opening all the coaching positions for Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: And I know this isn't a privy of the city council, but this is a forum that, unfortunately, as quickly as the word can get out, because this is an important topic, I talked to the superintendent.

[Scarpelli]: The word was on the street, and the superintendent and I discussed it in depth, that

[Scarpelli]: We are now putting in a policy in the middle of the summer that will now open up all the coaching positions and the athletic director, the big question was the athletic directors were not involved in the hiring, that the process is skewed and this is, you know, witch hunts.

[Scarpelli]: talk to the superintendent, the superintendent reassured me that the athletic directors are in full involvement with this process.

[Scarpelli]: They will be on top of the situation.

[Scarpelli]: This is something that and I shared my own personal opinion as a 32 year coach and athletic director and understanding the process that I shared my concerns that

[Scarpelli]: And that's where we've got some phone calls that during the fall season, the fall season starts in a few weeks.

[Scarpelli]: And the process is in place right now to

[Scarpelli]: have a committee put together.

[Scarpelli]: And the rumor was that it was gonna be just parents and kids hiring coaches, not true.

[Scarpelli]: The superintendent and I shared what we do in neighbor community where I'm part of that as a former coach, I'm also involved in the hiring team.

[Scarpelli]: That's between six to eight individuals.

[Scarpelli]: It's not two or three people.

[Scarpelli]: It's not people that are on there that don't like a coach that's sitting in the position right now.

[Scarpelli]: It's a position where we have the athletic directors, the assistant assistant athletic director, the the athletic trainer, you have two sitting seniors or captains that are coming back that season, and alumni that played that sport.

[Scarpelli]: You also have a parent and you have either a teacher in the school or a coach that's in the system.

[Scarpelli]: And so it's a whole, it's a whole committee.

[Scarpelli]: It's a true committee.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that, um, you know, that's, that's what we do.

[Scarpelli]: It's, it's very important that every school in the greater Boston league does that.

[Scarpelli]: I know that I talked to, uh, athletic director Maloney, he met with the superintendent.

[Scarpelli]: They had a great discussion when I was told that the process is exactly what, what I just said, that that's the hope.

[Scarpelli]: So again, let's, let's, you know, not jump ahead of it, not,

[Scarpelli]: it, you know, because kids are nervous, and I expressed the superintendent in this way, because of the fall season is what I'm a little concerned about.

[Scarpelli]: By the time the committee's put together, by the time the interviews are done, you're looking probably the middle of August, the season starts the third week of August.

[Scarpelli]: Using football, for example, if the football coach is let go and a new coach comes in, you are giving the student athletes that have been involved with this coach the last three years.

[Scarpelli]: This is every sport, girls' soccer, boys' soccer, golf, volleyball.

[Scarpelli]: coaches that involved last two months with the student athletes working camps, giving back to the community, kids getting in shape.

[Scarpelli]: The other piece that was was brought forth is you have coaches from colleges that are talking to student athletes, and they're discussing the possibility of being recruited and

[Scarpelli]: to make a coaching change this quick might be detrimental for their future.

[Scarpelli]: So the superintendent understood, we agreed to disagree.

[Scarpelli]: But I think that, you know, I think the process in place is a fair and open process.

[Scarpelli]: It's just like, like she said, it's an anomaly, because you have to start somehow, you have to start sometime.

[Scarpelli]: So my wish was starting for the winter season, if this is a process we move to.

[Scarpelli]: But again, I think the answer is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: It's not

[Scarpelli]: We didn't approve a gas station from BJ's.

[Scarpelli]: And we gave the wrong reasons why.

[Scarpelli]: And then what happened was BJ's came back because we didn't have legal representation.

[Scarpelli]: They sued us.

[Scarpelli]: They won.

[Scarpelli]: We had to go back to court.

[Scarpelli]: Now guess who's suing us?

[Scarpelli]: The residents.

[Scarpelli]: The residents are suing us because we're stuck in the middle because we don't have legal representation.

[Scarpelli]: We haven't had a city solicitor in a year.

[Scarpelli]: So we're not lawyers, we're elected officials that are trying to do best for our residents.

[Scarpelli]: So I know that we've got a report from our building department that our code enforcement officers are doing the best they can, unfortunately.

[Scarpelli]: the size of the city that we are now and what's going on in the city, only having a few enforcement officers, it's very difficult.

[Scarpelli]: We know that.

[Scarpelli]: Parking, we know that's a huge issue, huge concern.

[Scarpelli]: I have family members that live on Princeton Street that call me all the time.

[Scarpelli]: They think because I'm on the city council, I must own a tow truck.

[Scarpelli]: So I understand completely.

[Scarpelli]: open to the community, and there are no limitations other than making sure commercial vehicles aren't parked in there.

[Scarpelli]: And to be honest with you, they've done a great job since we met with them.

[Scarpelli]: I haven't heard the same complaints from different people.

[Scarpelli]: It's maybe one or two of the same people that are complaining.

[Scarpelli]: and maybe they have a right to, but the truth of the matter is they're doing the best they can.

[Scarpelli]: You know, the alternative is imagine if they're not there.

[Scarpelli]: But again, I'm not saying we should or we shouldn't because legally we don't know.

[Scarpelli]: So my recommendation truly is going to be to table this until we have a committee of the whole meeting

[Scarpelli]: We all have our thoughts.

[Scarpelli]: We all have our thoughts if Oasis was maybe a couple blocks away where it didn't, but a home, homes, they would say no, they're thriving, we don't want Oasis to leave, we need to have them, give them anything they want.

[Scarpelli]: Right, but then you have residents that are saying, listen, I mean, we had issues with, first it was, I remember the first phone call I got was the trucks are revving their engine in front of a window, keeping their engines running while they're running in to get something to eat in front of a resident's baby's bedroom window.

[Scarpelli]: And we stopped that completely.

[Scarpelli]: We ended up moving with the city and Oasis, we ended up bringing in planters, gigantic planters, so they couldn't park up on the curb.

[Scarpelli]: So that's just discussion.

[Scarpelli]: Maybe it's just a discussion we can have again, and see what we can do.

[Scarpelli]: Because I you know, and I'll do respect.

[Scarpelli]: You don't have control of your clientele, but you do have control of your people that work for you.

[Scarpelli]: And if you guys if we can all sit together and try to find a way that we can fix that, and help the neighbors and be part of the neighborhood community.

[Scarpelli]: And if it's something that we're bringing in the traffic enforcement saying, well, we need resident parking only.

[Scarpelli]: to rethink that and try to focus on how we're going to stop such a drastic move.

[Scarpelli]: money papers because we don't know where this is going to go when it comes to the presentation of the budget.

[Scarpelli]: I beg of you to please consider that I've been saying this and it's coming through fruition.

[Scarpelli]: from what teachers have called me, and they're appalled, and they don't know where they're going after what was supposed to be good faith negotiations and understanding the climate financially this community, and what is being told to me by the school department of teachers in the school department that they've been told that there will be cuts and layoffs.

[Scarpelli]: So every dollar right now we should really consider whether we're approving anything, dealing with money anything right now, until we have further understanding of what is going to happen in our community, when it comes to budget time because of the lack of information that have been shared to this council.

[Scarpelli]: We've been pushing money papers through because quote unquote what you said was, we still need to do the business of the city.

[Scarpelli]: But what we're doing is something unknown and what might happen is whatever we voted for is going to cause drastic trickle down effect in other areas in our community.

[Scarpelli]: So this is why I've said it, and believe me, I hate the fact that this looks like it's going to happen, that the budget is dire, that there are severe consequences that are happening.

[Scarpelli]: And I just, you know, I can only hope it's not true.

[Scarpelli]: But since we haven't had any information from anybody administration.

[Scarpelli]: I can only go with the people that reach out to me and share information, and that came directly from the school committee.

[Scarpelli]: Again, this is where we stand.

[Scarpelli]: You have your own conscious to vote on this, but understand, whatever you vote for, for one more dollar, whatever you vote on, when it comes to the budget season, and when it comes to the mayor looking at us and saying, we can't do what you want, and we're going to have to look at other positions, and then cut the assistant in the engineering department, or cut this program at the library, or cut this on our side, it falls on us.

[Scarpelli]: So again, I know it's a drastic conversation.

[Scarpelli]: But again, believe me, I wish I was wrong.

[Scarpelli]: in our HR department that this isn't a natural onboarding system where they come in, fill out the paperwork, do the GIC stuff together, and that happens.

[Scarpelli]: That's more alarming to me than anything because this wouldn't have happened if we didn't have a competent system in place like other communities.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't odd.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't new.

[Scarpelli]: This is, private entities, as they come in, if you work with a private entity and you walked in and you sat down with the HR directors of that company, that's part of the onboarding system of acquiring healthcare.

[Scarpelli]: That's probably one of the, after the salary, that's probably the most important thing you're looking at.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that that's what I'm more alarmed right now is that we don't have that process in place.

[Scarpelli]: Because I heard what you said, and what's alarming to me is that you're saying

[Scarpelli]: let the people that we're hiring, who, by the way, we're having a very difficult time finding people to work in Medford, that they have to come and search for you so they can get the benefits that they are required to have.

[Scarpelli]: Because every city employee

[Scarpelli]: is required to the option of GIC.

[Scarpelli]: So I don't know.

[Scarpelli]: I don't want to get in between what was said here, what was said there.

[Scarpelli]: I really don't.

[Scarpelli]: What I want is these three firefighters

[Scarpelli]: to get their insurance as quickly as possible.

[Scarpelli]: And if you'd like to, I'll share that tomorrow with the information that I can get to you, that there's contacts at GIC that I've worked with directly that can help with onboarding special situations, like seems to be this one.

[Scarpelli]: So this is, from what I gather, I'm not confused.

[Scarpelli]: From what I was told, Mr. Osborne, is that all three firefighters that are having issues all wanted the GIC and the city's insurance, correct?

[Scarpelli]: Okay, so for today, what I would love to do is get these three firefighters there tomorrow with our benefits officer and our HR director, and let's get the clock started tomorrow.

[Scarpelli]: compared to what we were looking for during negotiations when we heard the ridiculous numbers, when we talk about a city the size of Medford and the DPW team that we have and how limited it is, that hasn't changed, correct?

[Scarpelli]: I mean, you know, I'm hearing from from colleagues and neighbor communities that they they used to say they used to open a bottle of wine on a Tuesday night to watch Council Penter and Council Camuso go after each other.

[Scarpelli]: And they thought that was funny.

[Scarpelli]: The division in this great community is tragic

[Scarpelli]: Now, two heads are better than one, and four heads are better than two.

[Scarpelli]: Unified, we will overcome together.

[Scarpelli]: Very simple.

[Scarpelli]: This was when I wrote this, it was a few weeks back, and this was in conjunction with the horrifying situation for that young lady that endured the beating at Bedford High School and the lack of communication we got from the school department.

[Scarpelli]: I know that, you know, when I was in the school committee, one thing that we made sure that the superintendent reached out to all the stakeholders.

[Scarpelli]: And I know that when I was a school committee, we made sure that our city councils knew when something very important happened in the school department, that we would be getting phone calls, especially something that dire.

[Scarpelli]: And, um, we, we didn't get anything.

[Scarpelli]: I think we got a, uh, something that was added to a, um, go Mustang page and then something in it.

[Scarpelli]: It wasn't,

[Scarpelli]: It wasn't anything that we were alerted to because it's something that at that level.

[Scarpelli]: Now, don't get me wrong.

[Scarpelli]: We have a student that has an accident in the gym class.

[Scarpelli]: As a school committee member, I got a phone call saying, George, just so that you know, the ambulance just left from the Glynn School.

[Scarpelli]: We had a young person break their wrist in phys ed at basketball.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: I understand it's on the school committee side, just on the city side.

[Scarpelli]: we should be informed with issues that, especially dealing with the horrific issue that was brought to that situation, and newspapers and news trucks, and we're getting phone calls from news outlets, and we're getting phone calls from parents, but I don't know what you're talking about.

[Scarpelli]: And they said, how do you not know what we're talking about?

[Scarpelli]: So again,

[Scarpelli]: So thank you for hearing my cry, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Thanks for my colleagues.

[Scarpelli]: I think that I'm looking at this in a different way that we can look at it and showing showing our community how this can work.

[Scarpelli]: by going out in the community.

[Scarpelli]: I know that, you know, like I'll say it again, I hate to say it, but when you're working in a community, in a municipality, when you want something to change, you want something to happen, you go through the community, you set up round table events where people come out and share what their concerns are, and then the rebuttal or the communication back and forth to make sure this works.

[Scarpelli]: Now, traffic and parking fees and fines in our neighbor community,

[Scarpelli]: people were outraged after they went through roundtable discussions to each neighborhood.

[Scarpelli]: And they came back and they said, okay, so you're saying these fees and fines are going to go directly to our school system, that our roads will be swept on a daily basis and our playgrounds will be safe and clean.

[Scarpelli]: Well, let's see.

[Scarpelli]: And that's what happened.

[Scarpelli]: So the big conundrum, the big issue and concerns, the negativity was put to rest once people really understand where the benefits are and where that can go.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, what we're hearing over and over again is the lack of communication to who?

[Scarpelli]: The citizens of this community and

[Scarpelli]: That's where I agree with Councilor Knight that this cannot work and this won't work unless we have a way that we can turn to each other and say, this is how, why this is happening.

[Scarpelli]: Now, granted, when you're sitting in front of someone to tell them you're gonna raise fees and fines, they're gonna look you in the eye and tell you they're wrong.

[Scarpelli]: But ultimately, you made the decision to explain it and you move forward.

[Scarpelli]: We have yet to do that.

[Scarpelli]: in many things.

[Scarpelli]: My phone's been blowing up about how people were part of this dog commission, and this is something that, and Brookline, how things change and shame on you, and this is wrong.

[Scarpelli]: Fine, fine.

[Scarpelli]: I've talked to 30 of my neighbors that asked about this dog situation.

[Scarpelli]: They don't live in Brookline, they don't walk their dog off a leash, and there's a huge lack of communication in this community.

[Scarpelli]: The last two resolutions speak volumes.

[Scarpelli]: I think we saw a huge, huge difference with the relationship with the police and neighborhood policing when council Falco made this motion to move it to neighborhoods.

[Scarpelli]: And we actually joked about it because council Falco every week would give a summary and say, don't forget community policing will be held this night in this location.

[Scarpelli]: And you want, you want to know the truth?

[Scarpelli]: The police loved it, and the neighborhood loved it because that always filled the room.

[Scarpelli]: And they sat there, and like Chief used to say, they used to take it.

[Scarpelli]: And then when they were left, they were shaking hands saying, oh, now I understand.

[Scarpelli]: And boy, does that help.

[Scarpelli]: So communication is key for success in anything we do in life.

[Scarpelli]: And what we're lacking right now in this city is a true lack of communication.

[Scarpelli]: We put in strongholds to make sure that our kids are protected, putting in bullying protection programs, setting up mentoring programs, making sure the kids that don't want to be in the school and that are harming our children every single day, that they're the ones that are being looked at and those are the ones that are being taken to task.

[Scarpelli]: And unfortunately, what we hear over and over again, especially with this story with the Bramley family, it seems like that's not the priority right now.

[Scarpelli]: I told you in a meeting months ago when this happened,

[Scarpelli]: We're still seeing the uh, the the children that that that can't go to the bathroom because the the bad kids or the kids that don't care are using those bathrooms and And going kids not eating in cafeterias And finding little nooks and crannies to eat throughout the building.

[Scarpelli]: That's despicable That's horrifying to me and why

[Scarpelli]: and why the kids are telling me.

[Scarpelli]: They're telling me that the administration's in the buildings afraid to punish kids because of rules that are put into place.

[Scarpelli]: Well, I think we need to revisit these rules and make sure that we hold a school committee and our mayor and the school administration, the superintendent, to task, that this is their job.

[Scarpelli]: And I'm not talking as a city councilor, because I'm out of line if I was.

[Scarpelli]: I'm talking as a parent of a senior at Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: That is the parent.

[Scarpelli]: I'm committed to our brick and mortar businesses that have committed to this community, especially during the most difficult times, and bringing an outside entity into a neighborhood that's going to directly compete with a brick and mortar, and their sustainability throughout this process and, and their bounce back, I think that

[Scarpelli]: fees and permits requests and the limits that they have to live with while being a brick and mortar, as you well know.

[Scarpelli]: We find out when Donuts of the Difference calls us and says, George, we have people just coming in buying donuts, but they're not buying their coffee because they're going to the coffee cart down the street.

[Scarpelli]: that we haven't done our due diligence to see what our lives would look like by adding subcommittees on the other days, other than Tuesdays and Wednesdays, to see if we can still maintain the Tuesday night regular meetings.

[Scarpelli]: one of my first initiatives was looking at the charter view and making sure that we could revisit something that we haven't seen in so many years.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that had changed with me last time we voted, I voted no.

[Scarpelli]: And the reasons were very simple.

[Scarpelli]: It was so simple that what was asked for was yes or no and move forward.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's important that as you talk about a commission,

[Scarpelli]: One of the biggest things I think needs some debate is the understanding of ward and precinct representation.

[Scarpelli]: I think that sounds so easy for everybody and there are definitely some pros in that aspect of making sure that each ward are represented.

[Scarpelli]: speaking for myself, working in a municipality in a community that has ward and precinct representation, I see a lot of negative affects of that situation where it becomes a special interest option, special interest groups around the city.

[Scarpelli]: What I see is a lot of negativity in the sense that you have one community member and one part of the community holding

[Scarpelli]: their colleagues hostage in for what they want their initiatives to move forward not what's greater for their community as a whole, but for their small piece of the community and you could, I saw negative effects, a few times that.

[Scarpelli]: It didn't, it didn't help the community, and, and that's because of that and you know some other options that when you know you get a phone call from someone from South Medford or get a phone call from someone from West Medford or someone from the Walton Glenwood area.

[Scarpelli]: I work just as hard as if it was someone in my own backyard.

[Scarpelli]: So it gives people the opportunities to call seven different Councilors to really push an initiative, or a concern that they're not following so I see the benefits there I know that there are benefits to go through with it to look at that but again,

[Scarpelli]: when it was first presented as charter change or charter review, it was cut and dry.

[Scarpelli]: I had a great discussion with some members of the committee and talking about having a forum where we could discuss these options, where it's more of a thought process that it's discussed, it's understood, and maybe moving forward, it could be something that as you go forward with the initiative,

[Scarpelli]: and what you're looking for for charter review, at least.

[Scarpelli]: that answers to the DBW director, not that the DPW director has to ask the engineer who has to ask the Eversource engineer that they paid for it to see what happened or what's going on.

[Scarpelli]: I asked for a resolution was I asked for all the paving projects that was that were put out there for the last two years I got the report back which is great is all of the small

[Scarpelli]: jobs that were put out there, the Tufts, the C.J.

[Scarpelli]: Daugherty companies, you have the addresses.

[Scarpelli]: What I really wanted to see is all of the national grids, the Eversources, and what I got back was national grid, no address.

[Scarpelli]: Because when I drive to an area and a constituent has an issue with, oh, they cut this up, who is they?

[Scarpelli]: So they give me a time frame, so at least I can refer back as I drive by and say, oh, that looks like a job in front of 17 Butler Street, that that was a gas recut and they had to go back in because now that road is sinking, it's easy to go back and tell National Grid as we move forward, this is the work that you're doing.

[Scarpelli]: So again, it's frustrating to the point that we sit up here and people in the city that don't know the process and what happens come up here and the braid us because, and I don't begrudge them for that.

[Scarpelli]: This is what we're here for, but they braid us because the streets of this and the streets of that and the sidewalks of this and sidewalks of that.

[Scarpelli]: And most of the time, there's nothing to do with this body or the city employees.

[Scarpelli]: It has to do with the outside agencies that come into the city.

[Scarpelli]: their funding to make this happen, to bring in a clerk of the works that'll make sure they're doing what's best for the city of Medford, not for what the company that's giving them their paycheck by the end of the day.

[Scarpelli]: So again, Tim, again, this is no reflection on you.

[Scarpelli]: I know this is a difficult position you're in and that's all we keep hearing.

[Scarpelli]: our community.

[Scarpelli]: and start their own office with the administrative assistant and really getting to see what we wanna see for growth and diversity in our community.

[Scarpelli]: Because I know that it's not just on the police force, not just in the classroom, but it's also what our kids are talking about every day and what they're hearing every day.

[Scarpelli]: And a lot of times you learn from our children and I have two at home and you have to listen to them, you listen to their friends,

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Just comment.

[Scarpelli]: You know, it's been

[Scarpelli]: It's been bothersome to me as a first generation Italian American.

[Scarpelli]: I was fortunate enough to be raised by a wonderful Italian family.

[Scarpelli]: And I was taught lessons by probably one of the greatest men in the world, my dad, who studied in the Jesuit seminary.

[Scarpelli]: And he always told me as I started my journey as a school committee member and a Councilor, that no matter what the issue, put yourself on the other side.

[Scarpelli]: And he was, you know, his saint was Padre Pio, and it meant a lot to our family.

[Scarpelli]: And I hear the cries and I hear my neighbors that are upset.

[Scarpelli]: And the naming of the school, like my father would say, stepping aside, if it truly offended one person, it's something that we should look at.

[Scarpelli]: And if it really needed to be changed,

[Scarpelli]: we should look at that.

[Scarpelli]: I'm disgusted in the process.

[Scarpelli]: I thought the process wasn't something that we heard everyone, but why I decided to speak tonight is very important for the fact that I'm very proud of who I am as an Italian American.

[Scarpelli]: I wear that with a badge of honor and what I'm hearing from my neighbors, especially my older neighbors that made Medford such a great, great community with,

[Scarpelli]: with many other unbelievable nationalities is that they feel like they that they're being talked down to and they they've been thrown away and the heritage isn't what they brought to this community is not important.

[Scarpelli]: And that's what that's what bothers me, because I think if my mother and father, my grandparents felt that way, I'm doing a major disservice by sitting in the seat by not saying something.

[Scarpelli]: So my comments aren't just to just talk about it and let you know where I stand, but one thing that my father taught me and the Italian culture taught me, especially in Medford, we always found a way to bring everybody together.

[Scarpelli]: And I think Medford's screaming that.

[Scarpelli]: And to be honest with you, I think that most people on one side or the other, they feel the same way.

[Scarpelli]: They really do.

[Scarpelli]: And the people on the other side, they're all not animals.

[Scarpelli]: Besides that, when you hear side to side, and the people on this side, you're not disgusting animals.

[Scarpelli]: So there's gotta be something this community can do.

[Scarpelli]: My mother said to me, bring them all to a table, cook for them, let everybody sit at a table.

[Scarpelli]: look across the table from each other and talk to each other.

[Scarpelli]: And you realize how many things you have in common.

[Scarpelli]: We've heard new Medford, old Medford.

[Scarpelli]: That statement should be gone.

[Scarpelli]: It's Medford.

[Scarpelli]: We said this the other day when we lost Buddy Kelly.

[Scarpelli]: Buddy Kelly had a way as the athletic director to bring our community together.

[Scarpelli]: He made everybody feel like you were a Mustang.

[Scarpelli]: and you had one of the prerequisites of being a Mustang is that you had to have pride.

[Scarpelli]: And I think everybody that comes to this community, whether you are new or old, you have prides for this community.

[Scarpelli]: So I think what we need to do as elected officials and we need to do with the mayor's office is try to find that common ground, find a way we can bring everybody together.

[Scarpelli]: It could be something as a community event.

[Scarpelli]: that we bring everybody together and say, hey, let's sit down and let's just talk to each other and understand because some of my new neighbors I've talked to, they said, George, I'm just so disgusted with this group that doesn't understand that Columbus was a slave monger and it hurts people.

[Scarpelli]: And my discussions with those people and the understanding is that's really not the cry.

[Scarpelli]: The cry is that what Columbus meant to the Italian Americans at a very difficult time, they gave them, that symbol gave them an understanding of what America was and made them feel part of America when they didn't have a country.

[Scarpelli]: Something very similar that a lot of people in this country are going through right now, whether you're Latino, whether you're Brazilian, whether you're Haitian Creole and you're moving to this country,

[Scarpelli]: they want to be in our country.

[Scarpelli]: They love our country.

[Scarpelli]: This is what makes America great.

[Scarpelli]: So I, you know, I know we're not supposed to comment.

[Scarpelli]: We're not supposed to make motions.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't

[Scarpelli]: This isn't anywhere that we can do that, but as we move forward, I think that maybe this council can be creative enough to work together, all seven of us, and look at all of our groups that we work with and try to find a way with the office across the hall and maybe find a community event that brings everybody to the center of our town

[Scarpelli]: and celebrate it with cultural music and cultural foods and, and, and open tables.

[Scarpelli]: I mean, we have round tables for everything, but I'm almost sure the people in this room haven't really sat down and talked to people on the other side of that social media blog that they're beating up because they, there's just no communication.

[Scarpelli]: So someone told me my best quality when I first started as a, as a coach was I

[Scarpelli]: I did a great job bringing people together.

[Scarpelli]: And I think I'm on account of a great group of people that want to bring people together.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that as we move forward, when we can make motions and we can move forward, that we're creative enough to find something that'll help Medford heal.

[Scarpelli]: And it's so divided right now.

[Scarpelli]: And it's not comfortable for me.

[Scarpelli]: It's not comfortable for my children.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't what, this is how I wasn't raised.

[Scarpelli]: And we love Medford for a reason, just like the people that just came in on Carberry and just bought an $800,000 home because they want to be part of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: They want to be part of this community.

[Scarpelli]: So I think we have to find a way that we really work together.

[Scarpelli]: So, you know, you can't belittle the opinions of Ms.

[Scarpelli]: D'Antonio.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's how you feel and whether you like it or not, you still have to listen to those words.

[Scarpelli]: and vice versa.

[Scarpelli]: So I thank you for bringing this topic forward just so I can let my feelings, you know, be told that I haven't really expressed.

[Scarpelli]: I think that, um, you know, when I sit back and talk to my dad, these are the stories he tells me is he would have told me is to find a way to bring everybody together and use our culture and our heritage to do what's been done for years.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Yes.

[Scarpelli]: And thank you, Alicia and Danielle for being here.

[Scarpelli]: I think this is something that needs a little more teeth.

[Scarpelli]: code enforcement or the city solicitor.

[Scarpelli]: they look to turn these air conditioners or the heating systems on.

[Scarpelli]: But as you can see in New England weather and what we're seeing in different, we'll have days of 35 degrees one day, another day we'll have 90 degrees.

[Scarpelli]: So I think we have to have a way or we have to have an assistance here in the city of Medford where our city administration involved working with these assisted living homes where we're protecting our residents.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that from what I gathered, it was probably the most terrific

[Scarpelli]: situation where you're stuck on the fifth floor and there's no heat.

[Scarpelli]: I mean, there's no air conditioning that it was oppressive.

[Scarpelli]: So, which is dangerous for our residents.
