[Scarpelli]: cases of certain heat or cold, that we make sure that by code or by law, by ordinance, that we're taking steps to make sure we're protecting our residents.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: When I heard this news Friday morning, it was probably one of the toughest days because Buddy Kelly's played such a positive impact in my life and thousands of other residents here in the city of Medford and outside.

[Scarpelli]: First to his family, his wife, Judy, who stood beside him through two bouts of cancer.

[Scarpelli]: and the most awful fifth stage of Parkinson's disease.

[Scarpelli]: And his loving children, Beth, Judy, and Linda, who were there every step of the way for their dad.

[Scarpelli]: From what I hear, the last few months spent every single evening with him, making sure mom had the assistance that buddy's independence required.

[Scarpelli]: When I say this, I say this too often, maybe it starts to sound a little corny,

[Scarpelli]: This is happening too often when legends are leaving us here in Metro.

[Scarpelli]: And I thought of Buddy the other day and yesterday when we see our city going through a pretty tough time and it's so divided.

[Scarpelli]: And Buddy would be the type of person, no matter what race or gender, sexual orientation, what religion, your height, your color hair, or if you had no hair.

[Scarpelli]: He's the type of person that

[Scarpelli]: would find that bond to bring everybody together.

[Scarpelli]: And that's what I think we miss here right now in this community.

[Scarpelli]: And what I'm talking about is if you grew up in Medford and if you didn't grow up in Medford, you should learn about this because Buddy taught me some important lessons in life.

[Scarpelli]: I learned them in my home about loyalty and commitment and pride.

[Scarpelli]: And that's in your home.

[Scarpelli]: That's instilled in you by your mom and dad and your family, you hope.

[Scarpelli]: But Buddy taught you outside the home

[Scarpelli]: is what it all meant to be in Medford Mustang and be, and as he would say, blue and white, blue and white.

[Scarpelli]: And how that blue and white flow through your veins, no matter who you were.

[Scarpelli]: And it was funny as I read posts and talked to alumni and, you know, Krista McCormick, a legendary basketball player, captain of UMaine when I played professionally, she called us and she sent the message and said,

[Scarpelli]: But he was so amazing that he was the person back in the day that said to the girls' basketball program, to the boys' basketball program, hold on a second.

[Scarpelli]: The boys don't get the glass.

[Scarpelli]: The girls can shoot on that same glass the day before game day.

[Scarpelli]: So he changed the rule.

[Scarpelli]: And he made sure that everybody felt comfortable in Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: He had his own way, but his way was the Mustang way.

[Scarpelli]: He brought everybody together.

[Scarpelli]: And I'm going to miss him greatly because he did instill in me as a young coach and a young man what it was and why we live in the city of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: Because truly, whether you're here a day or whether you're here for 35 years, you're here for a reason.

[Scarpelli]: You moved here for a reason.

[Scarpelli]: You're brought here for a reason because you love the city of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: And if we can get back to what Buddy taught us for so many years and taught so many people that

[Scarpelli]: let the blue and white overcome everything else.

[Scarpelli]: And you could see amazing things happen.

[Scarpelli]: Like I said, last couple of nights, I've been thinking about buddy and seeing what our city is going through.

[Scarpelli]: And that analogy just came to me because it really meant a lot to me.

[Scarpelli]: That's the type of person that brought me into coaching.

[Scarpelli]: That's the type of person that when you sit in a locker room with my teams, that it wasn't about the win or the loss.

[Scarpelli]: It was about being a Mustang.

[Scarpelli]: and loving the blue and white and loving the city.

[Scarpelli]: And somewhere along the line, we forgot that.

[Scarpelli]: And I'd be remiss to say that if it wasn't for Buddy Kelly, I don't know if my life would ever be the same.

[Scarpelli]: He taught me so much and I'm gonna miss him forever.

[Scarpelli]: Present.

[Scarpelli]: started a committee to build new fields behind Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: And that's one of the number one cell areas in the country, we were told.

[Scarpelli]: Educators and scientists from MIT and Tufts that we didn't pay, they came in on their own, brought in by the community members because they worked at MIT or worked at Tufts, and they brought these professionals in that really helped all the neighbors understand what the scenarios were.

[Scarpelli]: You get, it falls into two sides, and that's what you're seeing happening in our community right now.

[Scarpelli]: You have people like the young lady who just spoke where, you know, how dumb are we?

[Scarpelli]: When it's affecting people in our community, how could we not want to support the Black Lives Matter sign?

[Scarpelli]: that they're using this statement as a political movement.

[Scarpelli]: Whether it's Medford, whether it is in Medford, as I talk to them, there is a divide.

[Scarpelli]: There's a divide in the black community about the Black Lives Matter, from the people I've talked to, my friends that I've talked to, and it's

[Scarpelli]: sad to the fact where I'm getting texts right now from Black members in our community, I won't say their names, that are telling me that All Lives Matter means it should be thrown away.

[Scarpelli]: Of course it should be.

[Scarpelli]: I would never, ever use the All Lives Matter in the context we're speaking in right now.

[Scarpelli]: Because we do have racial issues in our country.

[Scarpelli]: But I think it's important that

[Scarpelli]: We still have to understand this is a governing body that wants to support everybody in our community.

[Scarpelli]: But we also want to make sure that, like council said, we go through the process.

[Scarpelli]: And again, it's comical because for me talking, you've got to be careful what you're going to say.

[Scarpelli]: And I've said this when I first started running for office.

[Scarpelli]: I'm going to do what's right in my heart for what I think is best for the city of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: When I was a school team member, it was best for the kids in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: Now it's for everybody in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: And I have to live with the decisions I make, right or wrong.

[Scarpelli]: But it's comical that in a past meeting that I had hundreds of phone calls from my former players and my friends of color that said, George, why didn't you respond to that woman that called you a racist?

[Scarpelli]: And I said, geez, I'm sorry, my dog was barking and I happened to let my dog out and I couldn't defend myself.

[Scarpelli]: And I find myself sitting back saying, to use my background and what I've done for people, white, black, yellow, green, what I've done for people I would never use as a platform.

[Scarpelli]: But when it affects your family and affects your kids,

[Scarpelli]: And they're being talked about or brought out for something somebody says, the people that don't know each other.

[Scarpelli]: It stopped dividing this community.

[Scarpelli]: And the point that I'm trying to make is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: Black lives do matter.

[Scarpelli]: And as I stand with my friends of color, they know George Scott probably knows that.

[Scarpelli]: As a city councilor, I know that I want to follow the process that Councilor Marks has put forth.

[Scarpelli]: But again, Medford needs to start to heal.

[Scarpelli]: And we need to start to bring Medford back together again.

[Scarpelli]: There's a reason why everybody moved to Medford.

[Scarpelli]: Medford is a great community.

[Scarpelli]: We love Medford, all of us.

[Scarpelli]: All of us.

[Scarpelli]: Whether you're fighting for your own social causes, or whether you've lived here for 35 years, it doesn't matter.

[Scarpelli]: We have to find a common ground to bring Metro back together.

[Scarpelli]: Because I've heard so many people, the disappointment in our elderly, in our people that have just moved to the city, to say that, why are we so divided?

[Scarpelli]: We need to come together.

[Scarpelli]: So we need it from the leadership.

[Scarpelli]: Now the male will follow this process, and then we will follow this process.

[Scarpelli]: And if the Black Lives Matter sign hangs in Medford, and that now sends a message to everybody in our community that we stand together with Black lives, that's the process we went through.

[Scarpelli]: And we shall be proud of that.

[Scarpelli]: But at the same time, to say, everybody say that this isn't a political statement, this is what's dividing us.

[Scarpelli]: Because A, it is, and then B, the people that are looking at it the other side, they're not looking at it as how to help our black brothers and sisters.

[Scarpelli]: It's being looked at to say, well, let's look at that political group that's breaking our community down.

[Scarpelli]: And in a sense, yes, it does make some people look racist.

[Scarpelli]: And I don't think that's the intent.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, I'm not naive.

[Scarpelli]: Racism does exist.

[Scarpelli]: But I tell you, when I talk to my friends of color, and I talk to them, and how sad it is when they tell me that their kids are afraid to go to school because of one reason or another, or our white kids are afraid to go to school because they're put on a list that they've used a racial slur.

[Scarpelli]: It's dividing this community.

[Scarpelli]: We need to find something that's going to bring this together.

[Scarpelli]: So if we can follow through with Councilman Moxley's suggestions, and we make sure we dot our I's and cross our T's, and that's the resolution that we now hang the Black Lives Matter at Methodist City Hall, and that's the way we go.

[Scarpelli]: We need to find a way to stand together and heal and stop dividing.

[Scarpelli]: So believe me, I work in the community that first put that banner out, and I'm telling you, whatever you want to think, whether you're white or black, I heard from every single color that came to talk to me that looked at that as a platform instead of what's really intended for.

[Scarpelli]: And it divided people in that community, both black and white.

[Scarpelli]: And black people were for it, and black people were against it.

[Scarpelli]: So this is bigger, this is made up bigger than it really is.

[Scarpelli]: And it has, and it shouldn't.

[Scarpelli]: So all I beg to everybody in our community is let this take its course.

[Scarpelli]: And let's find a way to all come together and heal.

[Scarpelli]: Because when we voted on making

[Scarpelli]: making, um, uh, announcing, uh, racism, uh, public health emergency.

[Scarpelli]: I voted no on that.

[Scarpelli]: And I got feedback because I'm racist, but here we are here.

[Scarpelli]: We are months later.

[Scarpelli]: And like I said, nothing has been done as a community.

[Scarpelli]: We've done nothing to bring people together.

[Scarpelli]: I've asked for our black leaders in our community.

[Scarpelli]: I've asked for our black leaders in our schools to find a way that we can meet together with social distancing with the COVID.

[Scarpelli]: We could use that excuses to a blue in the face, but we need to meet together with the police chief, the superintendent of schools, the mayor, the city council, the school committee, everybody that makes the decision.

[Scarpelli]: So we all understand how we need to heal.

[Scarpelli]: And I know one council said, shame on you want, you want, now you want people to people of color to teach us what's wrong.

[Scarpelli]: Yes, we need to.

[Scarpelli]: Because that color of skin does not match theirs.

[Scarpelli]: And we've never lived what they're living through.

[Scarpelli]: So I apologize.

[Scarpelli]: Overly winded Mr. President, but I thought I knew that had to be said.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you.

[Scarpelli]: And again, Mr. President, I'm going to say, if I can interject, and I appreciate Councilor Morell for saying that, but it's easy to say what you just said.

[Scarpelli]: But the truth of the matter is, it is a political statement.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, it is.

[Scarpelli]: We could all say it's not, but unfortunately it is, on both sides.

[Scarpelli]: So we need to find a way to get through this and stop hailing from that.

[Scarpelli]: We have to acknowledge this stuff and move forward.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Mr. President, if I can.

[Scarpelli]: And this is what I'm talking about, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: A figure of speech has turned into something that I now have to read about racism.

[Scarpelli]: I've worked 35 years helping kids of color of the Latino race, Asian individuals.

[Scarpelli]: I've helped hundreds, if not thousands of kids.

[Scarpelli]: I've sat in their living rooms.

[Scarpelli]: They sat in my living rooms.

[Scarpelli]: They've cried to me for issues of race.

[Scarpelli]: They've come to me for guidance.

[Scarpelli]: I've gone to them for guidance.

[Scarpelli]: When we talk about race, I don't look at a book and read a book about race.

[Scarpelli]: I sit with my brothers and sisters that I coached and taught for 35 years.

[Scarpelli]: So when I say the people that called me racist, are there ignorant people that don't know George Scarpelli?

[Scarpelli]: Just because this Councilor wears his heart on his sleeve and will say what needs to be said does not make me weak because I'm a white privileged man.

[Scarpelli]: It makes me understand what we need to do to move forward and that is

[Scarpelli]: what I've learned by talking to my friends of color that I've talked to that they've sat at my dinner table and had dinner with my kids.

[Scarpelli]: So my son and daughter walk into a room, they don't see a color and thank God for that because we've always had an open door policy in the Scarpelli house that everybody was welcome.

[Scarpelli]: I never looked at a kid because of his color, the color of their skin.

[Scarpelli]: So maybe I have to educate people in who I am as a person.

[Scarpelli]: I don't need a book.

[Scarpelli]: I'll read it just to enlighten me a little, but to understand when I deal with racism, I deal with racism standing across the boys and girls, the men and women that I've helped in my life.

[Scarpelli]: That's who George Scarpelli is.

[Scarpelli]: George Scarpelli, when I brought up the racial comment,

[Scarpelli]: That was offensive to all the kids that I've helped in their lives, getting them into college, helping them fill out the FAFSAs.

[Scarpelli]: I envisioned, I've sat through systemic racism for 35 years as a high school soccer coach, trying to help kids get into college universities.

[Scarpelli]: So these are the concerns that I have with people in the community right now that have tagged people like George Scapelli and others

[Scarpelli]: as racist when you don't know who they are as people.

[Scarpelli]: So yes, we need to grow.

[Scarpelli]: We need to help.

[Scarpelli]: We need to make movement because there are racial issues in this country, in this community.

[Scarpelli]: But please, let's find a way to come together and not divide.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Point of information, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Again, and this is why when people speak from their heart, it's taken from the people's vision that's across them that they want to correct.

[Scarpelli]: When I say this, I do not, I've never in my life used about me.

[Scarpelli]: What I'm telling you, the education that I've gotten about racism doesn't come from anybody else, but the people that I work with every day.

[Scarpelli]: So I don't question who I am as a person and I'm not trying to defend myself or protect myself.

[Scarpelli]: I'm trying to enlighten the people that don't know George Scott belly to let them know that I've gone out and I've listened to people and I understand what they want.

[Scarpelli]: Yes.

[Scarpelli]: The clarification, especially this evening, I think that it is time to move forward and pass this on to the next step so we can get this process to fruition.

[Scarpelli]: So it's something I know that the Mifflin Brewing Company has been waiting for.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that the truth of the matter is it is time and it would seem to be prohibited if we didn't try to find our ways to make sure that

[Scarpelli]: we take care of the organizations that stuck with us through thick and thin.

[Scarpelli]: So, you know, I wish them the best of luck as we keep moving forward with the light stabilizers that they need, but I'm willing to move forward with this this evening.

[Scarpelli]: Our kids are afraid.

[Scarpelli]: Imagine getting into a classroom and teaching the situation of bringing this type of dangerous ammunition and weapons into our schools and understanding how we could teach our children how important and how scary this is because it is scary.

[Scarpelli]: Society today is scary.

[Scarpelli]: It's frightening.

[Scarpelli]: You know, I've talked to my kids about this just the other day.

[Scarpelli]: You know, Councilor Knight and I talked about this when I talked about our local government taking action.

[Scarpelli]: And then this happens.

[Scarpelli]: I'm so disappointed, so many different levels, because I'm going to beat the dead horse with this.

[Scarpelli]: It's bullets.

[Scarpelli]: It's ammunition to a weapon.

[Scarpelli]: of mass destruction, where kids have died just recently.

[Scarpelli]: So there is fear.

[Scarpelli]: There is heightened fear in this room and at home with our children.

[Scarpelli]: So I need you to understand.

[Scarpelli]: I know we don't want to be afraid and we don't want to, you know, we want to make sure that our kids feel safe in our schools.

[Scarpelli]: I absolutely agree with you, and we do a great job in our school system making sure we feel that way.

[Scarpelli]: But you know what, I think society has to realize, when things get done, it's out of fear.

[Scarpelli]: And this is fear, this is necessity now.

[Scarpelli]: And to have to start at this level, this is something that I'd have to put a huge black eye in what didn't happen in this role.

[Scarpelli]: This was bad.

[Scarpelli]: This was bad in so many different ways.

[Scarpelli]: that I'm sick of just even discussing.

[Scarpelli]: But moving forward, I know the parents need to talk, but we have so many members in our community, our school community, that you work so hard to protect and making sure that our students with mental issues and are disabled.

[Scarpelli]: These are our kids that are right in the front line of situations like this, that we need to get answers for to make sure they're protected.

[Scarpelli]: So, again, as a former colleague of many of those teachers there who taught with them and went through the lockdown situations in that course, I can understand, but we need to do more with this situation.

[Scarpelli]: We need to know that if it happens again, a bullet is enough, okay?

[Scarpelli]: A threat is enough that we have to let our children and our parents and our faculty know what's going on so we can prepare our children to make decisions what we think is right and safe for our children.

[Scarpelli]: So, again, believe me, I hate to be a heavy, but I tell you what, I am so sad and so disappointed that this wasn't presented in that fashion.

[Scarpelli]: I know Dan Tully, he's a very thorough individual, and I'm sure he brought it to the attention that it was going to be reported.

[Scarpelli]: and it wasn't.

[Scarpelli]: So I think we need to, you need to move on this.

[Scarpelli]: And I know that the investigation is one thing, but as a leader of our school system that I, that I entrust with you, we need to make, we need to make some hard decisions tonight.
